Multiple speakers

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

front.head: ENGLIGH-MEN For my Money: OR, A pleasant Comedy, called, A Woman will haue her Will. Pisaro, a Portingale. Laurentia, Pisaros Daughter. Marina, Pisaros Daughter. Mathea, Pisaros Daughter. Anthony, a Schoolemaister to them. Haruie, Suter to Pisaros Daughter. Ferdinand, or Heigham, Suter to Pisaros Daughter. Ned, or Walgraue, Suter to Pisaros Daughter. Delion, a Frenchman, Suter also to the 3. daughters. Aluaro, an Italian, Suter also to the 3. daughters. Vandalle, a Dutchman, Suter also to the 3. daughters. Frisco a Clowne, Pisaros man. M. Moore. Towerson a Marchant. Balsaro. Browne a Clothier A Post. A Belman.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: How smug this grey-eyed Morning seems to be,
A pleasant sight; but yet more pleasure have I
To think upon this moistening Southwest Wind,
That drives my laden Ships from fertile Spaine:
But come what will, no Wind can come amiss,
For two and thirty Winds that rules the Seas,
And blows about this airy Region;
Thirty two Ships have I to equal them:
Whose wealthy fraughts do make Pisaro rich:
Thus every Soil to me is natural:
Indeed by birth, I am a Portingale,
Who driven by Western winds on English shore,
Here liking of the soil, I married,
And have Three Daughters: But impartial Death
Long since, deprived me of her dearest life:
Since whose decease, in London I have dwelt:
And by the sweet loved trade of Usury,
Letting for Interest, and on Mortgages,
Do I wax rich, though many Gentlemen
By my extortion comes to misery:
Amongst the rest, three English Gentlemen,
Have pawned to me their Livings and their Lands:
Each several hoping, though their hopes are vain,
By marriage of my Daughters, to possess
Their Patrimonies and their Lands again:
But Gold is sweet, and they deceive themselves;
For though I guild my Temples with a smile,
It is but Iudas-like, to work their ends.
But soft, What noise of footing do I hear?

body.stage: Enter Laurentia, Marina, Mathea, and Anthony.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Now Master, what intend you to read to us?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Pisaro your Father would have me read moral Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: What is that?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: First tell me how you like it?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: First tell us what it is.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: They be my Daughters and their Schoolmaster,
Pisaro, not a word, but list their talk.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Gentlewomen, to paint Philosophy,
Is to present youth with so sour a dish,
As their abhorring stomachs nil digests.
When first my mother Oxford (Englands pride)
Fostered me pupil-like, with her rich store,
My study was to read Philosophy:
But since, my head-strong youths unbridled will,
Scorning the leaden fetters of restraint,
Hath pruned my feathers to a higher pitch.
Gentlewomen, Moral Philosophy is a kind of art,
The most contrary to your tender sexes;
It teacheth to be grave: and on that brow,
Where Beauty in her rarest glory shines,
Plants the sad semblance of decayed age:
Those Weeds that with their riches should adorn,
And grace fair Natures curious workmanship,
Must be converted to a black faced veil,
Griefs livery, and Sorrows semblance:
Your food must be your hearts abundant sighs,
Steeped in the brinish liquor of your tears:
Day-light as dark-night, dark-night spent in prayer:
Thoughts your companions, and repentant minds,
The recreation of your tired spirits:
Gentlewomen, if you can like this modesty,
Then will I read to you Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Fie upon it.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Hang up Philosophy, I will none of it.

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.l: A Tutor said I; a Tutor for the Devil.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No Gentlewomen, Anthony hath learned
To read a Lector of more pleasing worth.
Marina, read these lines, young Haruie sent them,
There every line repugns Philosophy:
Then love him, for he hates the thing thou hates.
Laurentia, this is thine from Ferdinande:
Think every golden circle that thou seest,
The rich unvalued circle of his worth.
Mathea, with these Gloves thy Ned salutes thee;
As often as these, hide these from the Sun,
And Wanton steals a kiss from thy fair hand,
Presents his serviceable true hearts zeal,
Which waits upon the censure of thy doom:
What though their Lands be mortgaged to your Father;
Yet may your Dowries redeem that debt:
Think they are Gentlemen, and think they love;
And be that thought, their true loves advocate.
Say you should wed for Wealth; for to that scope
Your Fathers greedy disposition tends,
The world would say, that you were had for Wealth,
And so fair Beauties honour quite distinct:
A mass of Wealth being poured upon another,
Little augments the show, although the sum;
But being lightly scattered by itself,
It doubles what it seemed, although but one:
Even so yourselves, for wedded to the Rich,
His style was as it was, a Rich man still:
But wedding these, to wed true Love, is duty:
You make them rich in Wealth, but more in Beauty:
I need not plead that smile, that smile shows hearts consent,
That kiss showed love, that on that gift was lent:
And last thine Eyes, that tears of true joy sends,
As comfortable tidings for my friends.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Have done, have done; what needest thou more procure,
When long ere this I stooped to that fair lure:
Thy ever-loving Haruie I delight it:
Marina ever loving shall requite it young.
Teach us Philosphy? I will be no Nun;
Age scorns Delight, I love it being:
There is not a word of this, not a words part,
But shall be stamped, sealed, printed on my heart;
On this I will read, on this my senses ply:
All Arts being vain, but this Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Why was I made a Maid, but for a Man?
And why Laurentia, but for Ferdinand?
The chastest Soul these Angels could entice?
Much more himself, an Angel of more price:
were it thyself present, as my heart could wish,
Such usage thou shouldest have, as I give this.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Then you would kiss him?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: If I did, how then?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Nay I say nothing to it, but Amen.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: The Clarke must have his fees, I will pay you them.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Good God, how abject is this single life,
I will not abide it; Father, Friends, nor Kin,
Shall once dissuade me from affecting:
A man is a man; and Ned is more than one:
In faith I will have thee Ned, or I will have none;
Do what they can, chafe, chide, or storm their fill,
Mathea is resolved to have her will.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I can no longer hold my patience.
Impudent villainy, and lascivious Girls,
I have overheard your vild conversions:
You scorn Philosophy: You will be no Nun,
You must needs kiss the Purse, because he sent it.
And you forsooth, you flurgill, minion,
A brat scant folded in the dozens at most,
You will have your will forsooth; What will you have?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: But twelve year old? nay Father that is not so,
Our Sexton told me I was three years more.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I say but twelve: you are best tell me I lie.
What sirrah Anthony.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Come here sir, and you light housewives get you in:
Stare not upon me, move me not to ire:
Nay sirrah stay you here, I will talk with you:
Did I retain thee (villain) in my house,
Gave thee a stipend twenty Marks by year,
And hast thou thus infected my three Girls,
Urging the love of those, I most abhorred;
Unthrifts, Beggars; what is worse,
And all because they are your Country-men?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Why sir, I taught them not to keep a Merchant's Book, or cast accompt: yet to a word much like that word Account.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A Knave past grace, is past recovery.
Why sirrah Frisco, Villain, Loggerhead, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Here is a calling indeed; a man were better to live a Lords life and do nothing, than a Serving creature, and never be idle. O Master, what a mess of Brews stands now upon the point of spoiling by your hastiness; why they were able to have got a good Stomach with child even with the sight of them; and for a Vapour, o precious Vapour, let but a Wench come near them with a Painted face, and you should see the Paint drop and curdle on her Cheeks, like a piece of dry Essex Cheese toasted at the fire.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sirrah, leave this thought, and mind my words,
Give diligence, inquire about
For one that is expert in Languages,
A good Musician, and a French-man born;
And bring him hither to instruct my Daughters,
I will never trust more a smooth-faced English-man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
What, must I bring one that can speak Languages,
what an old Ass is my Master; why he may speak flaunt taunt as well as French, for I cannot understand him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: If he speak French, thus he will say, Awee awee:
What, canst thou remember it?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O, I have it now, for I remember my great Grandfathers Grandmothers sisters cousin told me, that Pigs and French-men, speak one Language, awee awee; I am Dog at this: But what must he speak else?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Dutch.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Let us hear it?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Haunce butterkin slowpin .

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: O this is nothing, for I can speak perfect Dutch when I list.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Can you, I pray let us hear some?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay I must have my mouth full of Meat first, and then you shall hear me grumble it forth full mouth, as Haunce Butterkin slowpin frokin: No, I am a simple Dutch-man: Well, I will about it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Stay sirrah, you are too hasty; for he must speak one Language more.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: More Languages? I trust he shall have Tongues enough for one mouth: But what is the third?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Italian.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why that is the easiest of all, for I can tell whether he have any Italian in him even by looking on him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Can you so, as how?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry by these three points; a Wanton Eye. Pride in his Apparel, and the Devil in his Countenance. Well, God keep me from the Devil in seeking this French-man: But do you hear me Master, what shall my fellow Anthony do, it seems he shall serve for nothing but to put Latin into my young Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hence ass, hence loggerhead, begone I say.
And now to you that reads Philosophy,
Pack from my house, I do discharge thy service,
And come not near my doors; for if thou dost,
I will make thee a public example to the world.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well crafty Fox, you that work by wit,
It may be, I may live to fit you yet.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, this trick was spied in time,
For if but two such Lectures more they had heard,
Forever had their honest names been marred:
I will in and rate them: yet that is not best,
The Girls are wilful, and severity
May make them careless, mad, or desperate.
What shall I do? O! I have found it now,
There are three wealthy Merchants in the Town,
All Strangers, and my very special friends,
The one of them is an Italian:
A French-man, and a Dutch-man, be the other:
These three entirely do affect my Daughters,
And therefore mean I, they shall have the tongues,
That they may answer in their several Language:
But what helps that? they must not stay so long,
For while they are a-learning Languages,
My English Youths, both wed, and bed them too:
Which to prevent, I will seek the Strangers out,
Let us look: it is past eleven, Exchange time full,
There shall I meet them, and confer with them,
This work craves haste, my Daughters must be Wed,
For one Months stay, saith farewell Maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, we are almost at the house,
I promise you this walk over Tower-hill,
Of all the places London can afford,
Hath sweetest Air, and fitting our desires.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Good reason, so it leads to Croched-Fryers
Where old Pisaro, and his Daughters dwell,
Look to your feet, the broad way leads to Hell:
They say Hell stands below, down in the deep,
I will down that Hill, where such good Wenches keep,
But sirrah Ned, what says Mathea to thee?
Will it fadge? will it fadge? What, will it be a match?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: A match say you? a mischief it will as soon:
'sblood I can scarce begin to speak to her,
But I am interrupted by her father.
Ha, what say you? and then put over his snout,
Able to shadow Powles, it is so great.
Well, it is no matter, sirs, this is his House,
Knock for the Churl bid him bring out his Daughter;
I will, 'sblood I will, though I be hanged for it,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda, nothing with you but up and ride,
You will be within, ere you can reach the Door,
And have the Wench, before you compass her:
You are too hasty, Pisaro is a man,
Not to be fed with Words, but won with Gold.
But who comes here?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Whom, Anthony our friend?
Say man, how fares our Loves? How doth Mathea?
Can she love Ned? how doth she like my suit?
Will old Pisaro take me for his Son;
For I thank God, he kindly takes our Lands,
Swearing, Good Gentlemen you shall not want,
Whilst old Pisaro, and his credit holds:
He will be damned the Rogue, before he do it?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Prithee talk milder: let but thee alone,
And thou in one bare hour will ask him more,
Than he will remember in a hundred years:
Come from him Anthony, and say what news?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: The news for me is bad; and this it is:
Pisaro hath discharged me of his service.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Discharged thee of his service; for what cause?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Nothing, but that his Daughters learn Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Maids should read, that it teacheth modesty.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Aye, but I left out mediocrity,
And with effectual reasons, urged your loves.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: The fault was small, we three will to thy Master
And beg thy pardon.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: O, that cannot be,
He hates you far worser, than he hates me;
For all the love he shows, is for your Lands,
Which he hopes sure will fall into his hands:
Yet Gentlemen, this comfort take of me,
His Daughters to your loves affected be:
Their father is abroad, they three at home,
Go cheerly in, and cease that is your own:
And for myself, but grace what I intend,
I will overreach the Churl, and help my Friend.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Build on our helps, and but devise the means.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Pisaro did command Frisco his man,
(A simple sot, kept only but for mirth)
To inquire about in London for a man,
That were a French-man and Musician,
To be (as I suppose) his Daughters Tutor:
Him if you meet, as like enough you shall,
He will inquire of you of his affairs;
Then make him answer, you three came from Paules,
And in the middle walk, one you espied,
Fit for his purpose; then describe this Cloak,
This Beard and Hat: for in this borrowed shape,
Must I beguile and over-reach the Fool:
The Maids must be acquainted with this drift.
The Door doth ope, I dare not stay reply,
Lest being descried: Gentlemen adieu,
And help him now, that oft hath helped you.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: How now sirrah, whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Whither am I going, how shall I tell you, when I do not know myself, nor understand myself?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Marry sir, I am seeking a Needle in a Bottle of Hay, a Monster in the likeness of a Man: one that instead of good morrow, asketh what Porridge you have to Dinner, Parley vous signiour? one that never washes his fingers, but licks them clean with kisses; a clipper of the Kings English: and to conclude, an eternal enemy to all good Language.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: What is this? what is this?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Do not you smell me? Well, I perceive that wit doth not always dwell in a Satin-doublet: why, it is a French-man, Bassimon cue, how do you?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: I thank you sir, but tell me what wouldst thou do with a French-man:

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Nay faith, I would do nothing with him, unless I set him to teach Parrots to speak: marry the old Ass my Master, would have him to teach his Daughters, though I trust the whole world sees, that there be such in his house that can serve his Daughters turn, as well as the proudest French-man: but if you be good lads, tell me where I may find such a man?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: We will, go hie thee straight to Paules,
There shalt thou find one fitting thy desire;
Thou soon mayst know him, for his Beard is black,
Such is his raiment, if thou runnest apace,
Thou canst not miss him Frisco.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p:
Lord, Lord, how shall poor Phrisco reward your rich tidings Gentlemen: I am yours till Shrove tuesday, for then change I my Copy, and look like nothing but Red-Herring Cobs, and Stock-Fish; yet I will do somewhat for you in the mean time: my Master is abroad, and my young Mistresses at home: if you can do any good on them before the French-man come, why so? Ah Gentlemen, do not suffer a litter of Languages to spring up amongst us: I must to the Walk in Paules, you
to the Vestry. Gentlemen, as to myself, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Fools tell the truth men say, and so may he:
Wenches we come now, Love our conduct be.
Ned, knock at the door: but soft forbear;
The Cloud breaks up, and our three Suns appear.
To this I fly, shine bright my lives sole stay,
And make griefs night a glorious summers day.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Gentlemen, how welcome you are here,
Guess by our looks, for other means by fear
Prevented is: our fathers quick return
Forbids the welcome, else we would have done.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Mathea, How these faithful thoughts obey,

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: No more sweet love, I know what thou wouldst say:
You say you love me, so I wish you still,
Love hath loves here, being balanced with good will:
But say; come you to us, or come you rather
To pawn more Lands for money to our father?
I know it is so, in Gods name spend at large:
What man? our marriage day will all discharge;
Our father (by his leave) must pardon us,
Age save of age, of nothing can discuss:
But in our loves, the proverb we will fulfil:
Women and Maids, must always have their will.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Say thou as much, and add life to this Coarse,

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Yourself and your good news doth more enforce:
How these have set forth love by all their wit,
I swear in heart, I more than double it.
Sisters be glad, for he hath made it plain,
The means to get our Schoolmaster again:
But Gentlemen, for this time cease our loves,
This open street perhaps suspicion moves,
Fain we would stay; bid you walk in more rather,
But that we fear the coming of our father:
Go to the Exchange, crave Gold as you intend,
Pisaro scrapes for us; for us you spend:
We say farewell, more sadly be bold,
Than would my greedy father to his Gold:
We here, you there, ask Gold; and Gold you shall:
We will pay the interest, and the principal.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: That is my good Girls, and I will pay you for all.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Come to the Exchange, and when I feel decay,
Send me such Wenches, Heavens I still shall pray.

body.stage: Enter Pisaro, Delion the Frenchman, Vandalle the Dutchman, Aluaro the Italian, and other Marchants, at seuerall doores.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Good morrow, M. Strangers.

sp.speaker: Strang.
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: This (loving friends) hath thus emboldened me,
For knowing the affection and the love
Master Vandalle, that you bear my Daughter:
Likewise, and that with joy considering too,
you Monsieur Delion, would fain dispatch:
I promise you, methinks the time did fit,
And does by our Lady too, in mine advice,
This day to clap a full conclusion up:
And therefore made I bold to call on you,
Meaning (our business done here at the Burse)
That you at mine entreaty should walk home,
And take in worth such Viands as I have:
And then we would, and so I hope we shall,
Loosely tie up the knot that you desire,
But for a day or two; and then Church rites
Shall sure conform, consume, and make all fast.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Seker Master Pisaro, me do so groterly thank you, that you mick me so sure of the Wench, that I can not thank you enough.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p:
Monsieur Pisaro, mon pere, mon Vadere , O the
grandee joy you give me (oconte) me shall go home to your House, shall eat your Bacon, shall eat your Beef, and shall take the Wench, the fine Damoiselle.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You shall, and welcome; welcome as my soul:
But were my third Son sweet Aluaro here,
We would not stay at the Exchange today,
But hie us home and there end our affairs.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Good day master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Master Moore, marry with all my heart good morrow sir; What news? What news?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: This Merchant here my friend, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: Sir, this jolly South-west wind with gentle blast,
Hath driven home our long expected Ships,
All laden with the wealth of ample Spaine,
And but a day is past since they arrived
Safely at Plimmouth, where they yet abide.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thanks is too small a guerdon for such news.
How like you this News friends? Master Uandalle,
Here is somewhat towards for my Daughters Dowry:
Here is somewhat more than we did yet expect.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But hear you sir, my business is not done;
From these same Ships I did receive these lines,
And there enclosed this same Bill of exchange,
To pay at sight; if so you please accept it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Accept it, why? What sir should I accept,
Have you received Letters, and not I?
Where is this lazy villain, this slow Post;
What, brings he every man his Letters home,
And makes me nobody; does he, does he?
I would not have you bring me counterfeit;
And if you do, assure you I shall smell it:
I know my Factors writing well enough.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: You do sir; then see your Factors writing:
I scorn as much as you, to counterfeit,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: It is well you do sir.
What Master Walgraue, and my other friends:
You are grown strangers to Pisaros house,
I pray make bold with me.

sp.speaker: Walsg.
sp.l: Aye with your Daughters
You may be sworn, we will be as bold as may be.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Would you have aught with me, I pray now speak.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Sir, I think you understand our suit,
By the repairing we have had to you:
Gentlemen you know, must want no Coin,
Nor are they slaves unto it, when they have:
You may perceive our minds; What say you to it?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Gentlemen all, I love you all:
Which more to manifest, this afternoon
Between the hours of two and three repair to me;
And were it half the substance that I have,
Whilst it is mine, it is yours to command.
But Gentlemen, as I have regard to you,
So do I wish you will have respect to me:
You know that all of us are mortal men,
Subject to change and mutability;
You may, or I may, soon pitch over the Perch,
Or so, or so, have contrary crosses:
Wherefore I deem but mere equity,
That something may betwixt us be to show.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, within this two months without fail,
We will repay.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.l: God save you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Gentlemen.
sp.l: Good morrow sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What M. Brown, the only man I wished for,
Does your price fall? what shall I have these Clothes?
For I would ship them straight away for Stoade:
I do wish you my Money fore another.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Faith you know my price sir, if you have them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You are too dear in sadness, master Heigham:
You were about to say somewhat, pray proceed.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Then this it was: those Lands that are not mortgaged

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: God bless your worship.

sp.speaker: Pisaro.
sp.l: I must crave pardon; O sirrah, are you come?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda; What is the matter now;
Sure, yonder fellow will be torn in pieces.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: What is he, sweet youths; that so they flock about:
What old Pisaro tainted with this madness?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Upon my life, it is somebody brings news;
The Court breaks up, and we shall know their Counsel:
Look, look, how busily they fall to reading.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am the last, you should have kept it still:
Well, we shall see what news you bring with you;

sp.p: Our duty premised, and we have sent unto your worship Sack, siuill Oils, Pepper, Barbery sugar, and such other commodities as we thought most requisite, we wanted money therefore we are fain to take up 200. l. of Master Towersons man, which by a bill of Exchange sent to him, we would request your worship pay accordingly.

sp.l: You shall command sir, you shall command sir,

sp.p: The news here is, that the English ships, the Fortune, your ship, the adventure and good luck of London coasting along by Italy Towards Turky, were set upon by two Spanish-galleys, what became of them we know not, but doubt much by reason of the weathers calmness.

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: How is it six to one the weather calm,
Now afore God who would not doubt their safety,
A plague upon these Spanish-galley Pirates,
Roaring Caribdis, or devouring Scilla,
Were half such terror to the antic world,
As these same antic Villains now of late,
Have made the Straights twixt Spaine and Barbary.

sp.speaker: Tower
sp.l: Now sir, what doth your Factors letters say?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry he saith, these witless luckless dolts,
Have met, and are beset with Spanish Galleys,
As they did sail along by Italy:
What a bots made the dolts near Italy,
Could they not keep the coast of Barbary,
Or having past it, gone for Tripoly,
Being on the other side of Sicily,
As near, as where they were unto the Straights:
For by the Globe, both Tripoly and it,
Lie from the Straights some twenty five degrees;
And each degree makes three-score english miles?

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.p: Very true sir: But it makes nothing to my Bill of exchange: this dealing fits not one of your account.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And what fits yours? a prating wrangling tongue,
A woman's ceaseless and incessant babbling,
That sees the world turned topsy turvy with me;
Yet hath not so much wit to stay a while,
Till I bemoan my late excessive loss.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'swounds it is dinner time, I will stay no longer:
Hark you a word sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I tell you sir, it would have made you whine
Worse than if shoals of luckless croaking Ravens,
Had seized on you to feed their famished paunches:
Had you heard news of such a ravenous rout,
Ready to cease on half the wealth you have.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: 'sblood you might have kept at home and be hanged,
What a pox care I.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: God save your worship, a little money and so forth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But men are senseless now of others woe,
This stony age is grown so stony hearted,
That none respects their neighbours miseries,
I wish (as Poets do) that Saturnes times
The long out worn world were in use again,
That men might sail without impediment.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Aye marry sir that were a merry world indeed, I would hope to get more money of your worship in one quarter of a year, than I can do now in a whole twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: Master Pisaro how I have run about,
How I have toiled today to find you out,
At home, abroad, at this man's house, at that,
Why I was here an hour ago and more,
Where I was told you were, but could not find you.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Faith sir I was here but was driven home,
Here is such a common haunt of Crack-rope boys,
That what for fear to have my apparel spoiled,
Or my Ruffs dirtied, or Eyes struck out:
I dare not walk where people do expect me:
Well, things (I think) might be better looked unto,
And such Coin too, which is bestowed on Knaves,
Which should, but do not see things be reformed,
Might be employed to many better uses:
But what of beardless Boys, or suchlike trash;
The Spanish Galleys: O, a vengeance on them.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Mass, this man hath the luck on it, I think I can scarce ever come to him for money, but this a vengeance on, and that; a vengeance on it, doth so trouble him, that I can get no Coin: Well, a vengeance on it for my part; for he shall fetch the next Letters himself.

sp.speaker: Browne.
sp.l: I prithee, when thinkst thou the Ships will be come about from Plimmouth?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Next week, sir.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Came you sir from Spaine lately?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: Aye sir; Why ask you that?

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.p: Marry sir, thou seems to have been in the hot countries, thy face looks so like a piece of rusty Bacon: had thy Host at Plimmoth meat enough in the house, when thou wert there?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: What though he had not sir? but he had, how then?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry thank God for it; for otherwise, he would doubtless have Cut thee out in Rashers to have eaten thee; thou lookest as thou wert through broiled already.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: You have said sir; but I am no meat for his moing, nor yours neither: If I had you in place where, you should find me tough enough in digestion, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What will you swagger sirrah, will ye swagger?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: I beseech you Sir, hold your hand; Get home ye patch, cannot you suffer Gentlemen Jest with you?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I would teach him a Gentle trick if I had him of the burse; but I will watch him a good turn I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Assure ye master Towerson, I cannot blame him,
I warrant you it is no easy loss;
How think you master Stranger? by my faith sir,
There is twenty Merchants will be sorry for it,
That shall be partners with him in his loss.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.l: Why sir, what is the matter.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: The Spanish-galleys have beset our ships,
That lately were bound out for Siria.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: What not? I promise you I am sorry for it.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What an old Ass is this to keep us here:
Master Pisaro, pray dispatch us hence.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Master Vandalle I confess I wrong you;
But I will but talk a word or two with him, and straight turn to you.
Ah sir, and how then i'faith?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Turn to us, turn to the Gallows if you will,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: It is Midsummer-Moon with him: let him alone,
He calls Ned Walgraue, Master Vandalle.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Let it be shrovetide, I will not stay an inch master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What should you fear: and as I have vowed before,
So now again; my Daughters shall be yours:
And therefore I beseech you and your friends,
Defer your business till Dinner time;
And what you would say, keep it for table talk.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Marry and shall; a right good motion:
sirs, old Pisaro is grown kind of late,
And in pure love, hath bid us home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Good news in truth: But wherefore art thou sad?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: For fear the slave ere it be dinner time,
Remembering what he did, recall his word:
For by his idle speeches, you may swear,
His heart was not confederate with his tongue.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Tut never doubt, keep stomachs till anon,
And then we shall have cates to feed upon.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well sir, since things do fall so crossly out,
I must dispose myself to patience:
But for your business, do you assure yourself,
At my repairing home from the Exchange,
I will set a helping hand unto the same.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bon iurno signeour Padre, why be the melancholy so much, and grave in you: what News make you look so naught?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Naught is too good an epithet by much,
For to distinguish such contrariness:
Hath not swift Fame told you our slow sailed Ships
Have been overtaken by the swift sail Galleys,
And all my cared-for goods within the lurch
Of that same Caterpillars brood of Spaine.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Seignior fie, how the Spaniola have almost taken the Ship that go for Turkie: my Pader, hark you me on word, I have receive a letter from my Factor de Vennise, that after vn piculo battalion, for a half hour de come a Wind from the North, and the Sea go tumble here, and tumble there, that make the Galleys run away for fear be almost drowned.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How sir; did the Wind rise at North, and Seas wax rough: and were the Galleys therefore glad to fly?

sp.speaker: Alu.
sp.l: Seignior si, and the Ship go right on the Iscola Candy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Wert thou not my Aluaro my beloved,
One whom I know does dearly count of me,
Much should I doubt me that some scoffing lack,
Had sent thee in the middest of all my griefs,
To tell a feigned tale of happy luck.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Will you not believe me? see there then, see the letter.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What is this world? or what this state of man,
How in a moment cursed, in a trice blessed?
But even now my happy state gan fade,
And now again, my state is happy made,
My Goods all safe, my Ships all scaped away,
And none to bring me news of such good luck,
But whom the Heavens have marked to be my Son:
Were I a Lord as great as Alexander,
None should more willingly be made mine Heir
Than thee thou golden tongue, thou good-news teller
Joy stops my mouth.

sp.speaker: Balsa.
sp.l: M. Pisaro, the day is late, the Bell doth ring:
Will it please you hasten to perform this business?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What business sir? Gods me, I cry you mercy:
Do it, yes sir, you shall command me more.

sp.speaker: Tower.
sp.l: But sir, What do you mean, do you intend
To pay this Bill, or else to palter with me?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry God shield, that I should palter with you:
I do accept it, and come when you please;
You shall have money, you shall have your money due.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.l: I beseech your worship to consider me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: O, you cannot cog: Go to, take that,
Pray for my life: pray that I have good luck,
And thou shalt see, I will not be thy worst master.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p: Marry God bless your Worship; I came in happy time: What, a French crown? sure he knows not what he does: Well, I will begone, lest he remember himself, and take it from me again

sp.speaker: Pisa
sp.l: Come on my lads, M. Vandalle, sweet son Aluaro:
Come don Balsaro, let us be jogging home
By our laken sirs, I think it is one o'clock.

body.stage: Exit Pisaro, Balsaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Uandalle.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Come M. Moore, the Exchange is waxen thin,
I think it best we get us home to dinner.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: I know that I am looked for long ere this:
Come master Towerson, let us walk along.

body.stage: Exit Moore, Browne, Towerson, Strangers, & Marchant.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And if you be so hot upon your dinner,
Your best way is, to haste Pisaro on,
For he is cold enough, and slow enough;
He hath so late digested such cold news.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Marry and shall: Hear you master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Many Pisaros here: Why how now Ned;
Where is your Matt your welcome, and good cheer?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'swounds, let us follow him; why stay we here?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay prithee Ned Walgrave let us bethink ourselves,
There is no such haste, we may come time enough:
At first Pisaro bade us come to him
Twixt two or three o'clock at afternoon?
Then was he old Pisaro: but since then,
What with his grief for loss, and joy for finding,
He quite forgot himself, when he did bid us,
And afterwards forgot, that he had bade us.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I care not, I remember it well enough:
He bade us home; and I will go, that is flat,
To teach him better wit another time.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Here will be a gallant jest, when we come there,
To see how mazed the greedy chuff will look
Upon the nations, sects, and factions,
That now have borne him company to dinner:
But hark you, let us not go to vex the man;
Prithee sweet Ned let us tarry, do not go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Not go? indeed you may do what you please;
I will go, that is flat: nay, I am gone already,
Stay you two, and consider further of it.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Nay all will go, if one: I prithee stay;
Thou art such a rash and giddy headed youth,
Each Stone is a Thorne: Hoyda, he skips for haste;
Young Haruie did but jest; I know he will go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay, he may choose for me: But if he will,
Why does he not? why stands he prating still?
If you will go, come: if not, fare-well?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Hire a Post horse for him (gentle Francke)
Here is haste, and more haste than a hasty Pudding:
You mad-man, mad-cap, wild-oats; we are for you,
It boots not stay, when you intend to go.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Come away then.

body.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Uandalle.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A thousand welcomes friends: Monsieur Delion,
Ten thousand Ben-venues unto yourself.
Seignior Aluaro, Master Vandalle;
Proud am I, that my roof contains such Friends.
Why Mall, Larentia, Matth; Where be these Girls?
Lively my Girls, and bid these Strangers welcome;
They are my friends, your friends, and our well-willers:
You cannot tell what good you may have on them.
Gods me, Why stir you not? Hark in your ear,
These be the men the choice of many millions,
That I your careful Father have provided
To be your Husbands: therefore bid them welcome.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Nay by my troth, it is not the guise of maids,
To give a slavering Salute to men:
If these sweet youths have not the wit to do it,
We have the honesty to let them stand.

p.foreign: Gods sekerlin, dats vn-fra meskin, Monsieur Delion there the Grote freisler, there wode I zene, it is vn-fra Daughter, there hebic so long loude, there Heb my desire so long gewest.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Ah Uenice, Roma, Italia, Frauncia, Anglitera, nor all this orb can show so much belliza, veremante de secunda, Madona de granda bewtie.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Certes me dincke de mine depeteta de little Angloise, de me Matresse Pisaro is vn nette, vn becues, vn fra, et vn tendra Damosella.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What Stocks, what stones, what senseless Trunks be these?
When as I bid you speak, you hold your tongue:
When I bid peace, then can you prate, and chat,
And gossip: But go too, speak and bid welcome;
Or (as I live) you were as good you did.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: I cannot tell what Language I should speak:
If I speak English (as I can none other)
They cannot understand me, nor my welcome.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Bella Madonna, there is no language so dulce; dulce, that is sweet, as the language, that you shall speak, and the welcome that you shall say, shall be well know perfectly.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Pray sir, What is all this in English?

sp.speaker: Alua.
Pisa.
sp.l: And that methinks sir, not without need:
And with Italian, to a Childes obedience,
With such desire to seek to please their Parents,
As others far more virtuous than themselves,
Do daily strive to do: But it is no matter,
I will shortly pull your haughty stomachs down:
I will teach you urge your Father; make you run,
When I bid run: and speak, when I bid speak:
What greater cross can careful parents have
Than careless Children. Stir and see who knocks?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Good morrow to my good Mistress Mathea.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: As good a morrow, to the morrow giver.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A murrain, what make these? What do they here?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: You see master Pisaro, we are bold guests,
You could have bid no surer men than we.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hark you Gentlemen; I did expect you
At afternoon, not before two o'clock.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Why sir, if you please, you shall have us here at two o'clock, at three o'clock, at four is; nay till tomorrow this time: yet I assure you sir, we came not to your house without inviting.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why Gentlemen, I pray who bade you now?
Whoever did it, sure hath done you wrong:
For scarcely could you come to worser cheer.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: It was your own self bade us to your cheer,
When you were busy with Balsaro talking;
You bade us cease our suites till dinner time,
And then to use it for our table talk:
And we I warrant you, are as sure as Steel.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A murrain on yourselves, and sureness too:
How am I crossed: Gods me, what shall I do,
This was that ill news of the Spanish Pirates,
That so disturbed me: well, I must dissemble,
And bid them welcome; but for my Daughters
I will send them hence, they shall not stand and prate.
Well my Masters, Gentlemen, and Friends,
Though unexpected, yet most heartily welcome;
(Welcome with a vengeance) but for your cheer,
That will be small: yet too too much for you.
Mall, in and get things ready.
Laurentia, bid Maudlin lay the Cloth, take up the Meat:
Look how she stirs; you sullen Else, you Callet,
Is this the haste you make:

p.foreign: Signor Pisaro, ne soiat so malcontento de Gentlewoman your filigola did parler but a litella to, the gentle homa your graunde amico.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But that graunde amico, is your grande inimico:
One, if they be suffered to parley,
Will poll you, aye and pill you of your Wife:
They love together: and the other two,
Loves her two Sisters: but it is only you
Shall crop the flower, that they esteem so much.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Do they so; well let me lone, shall see me give them the such grand mock, shall be shame of themselves.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Do sir, I pray you do; set lustily upon them,
And I will be ready still to second you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: But Matt, art thou so mad as to turn French?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Yes marry when two Sundays come together;
Think you I will learn to speak this gibberish,
Or the Pigs language? Why, if I fall sick,
They will say, the French (et-cetera) infected me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Minion; what, is this your service?
Your other Sisters busy are employed,
And you stand idle: get you in, or.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: If you chide her, chide me (M. Pisaro:
For but for me, she had gone in long since.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I think she had: for we are sprites to scare her;
But ere it be long, I will drive that humour from her.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Seignior, methinks you should no mick the wench so hardy, so disobedient to the padre as that madonna Matt.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.p: Seignior, methinks you should learn to speak, before you should be so foolhardy, as to woe such a Maiden as that Madonna Matt?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Warrant you Monsieur, he shall parley when you shall stand out the door.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Hark you Monsieur, you would wish yourself half hanged, you were as sure to be let in as he.

sp.speaker: Uan.
sp.l: Mick no doubt the seignior

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: shall do well enough

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: perhaps so: but methinks your best way were to ship yourself for Stoad, and there to batter yourself for a commodity; for I can tell you, you are here out of liking.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: The worst perhaps dislike him, but the best esteem him best.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: But by your patience sir, methinks none should know better who is Lord, than the Lady.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Than the Lady, what Lady?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.p: Marry sir, the Lady let her alone: one that means to let you alone for fear of trouble.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Every man as he may: yet sometimes the blind may catch a Hare.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: I sir, but he will first eat many a Fly:
You know it must be a wonder, if a Crab catch a Fowl.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Maer hort ens; if he and I and monsieur Delion be the Crab, we shall catch the Fowl well enough, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Aye and the Fool well enough I warrant you; And much good may it do ye.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Methinks such a piccolo man as you be, shall have no the such grandee luck madere.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Non da Monsieur, if he be so grand amorous of the Damoiselle, he shall have Mawdlyn the wit wench in the Kitchen by master Pisaros leave.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: By M. Pisaros leave, Monsieur I will mumble you, except you learn to know, whom you speak to: I tell thee Francois, I will have (maugre thy teeth) her that shall make thee gnash thy teeth to want.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Yet a man may want of his will, and bate an Ace of his wish: But Gentlemen, every man as his luck serves, and so agree we; I would not have you fall out in my house: Come, come, all this was in jest, now let us to it in earnest; I mean with our teeth, and try who is the best Trencher-man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Ah sirrah, now I know, what manner of thing Powles is; I did so marvel afore what it was out of all count: For my master would say, Would I had Powles full of Gold. My young Mistresses, and Grimkin our Taylor, would wish they had Powles full of Needles: Aye, one asked my master half a yard of Freeze to make me a Coat and
he cried whoop holly-day, it was big enough to make Powles a Nightgown. I have been told, that Duke Humfrie dwells here, and that he keeps open house, and that a brave sort of Cammileres dine with him every day; now if I could see any vision in the world towards dinner, I would set in a foot: But the best is, a the ancient English romaine Orator saith, So-lame-men, Misers, Housewives, and so forth: the best is, that I have great store of company that do nothing but go up and down, and go up and down, and make a grumbling together, that the meat is so long making ready: Well, if I could meet this scurvy Frenchman, they should stay me, for I would be gone home.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I beseech you Monsieur, give me audience.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: What would you have? What should I give you?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Pardon, sir mine uncivil and presumptuous intrusion, who endeavour nothing less, than to provoke or exasperate you against me.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: They say, a word to the Wise is enough: so by this little French that he speaks, I see he is the very man I seek for: Sir, I pray what is your name?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: I am nominated Monsieur Le Mouche, and rest at your bon service.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: I understand him partly; yea, and partly nay:
Can you speak French? Content pore vous monsieur Madomo.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: If I could not sir, I should ill understand you: you speak the best French that ever trod upon Shoe of Leather.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Nay, I can speak more Languages than that:
This is Italian, is it not? Nella slurde Curtezana.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Yes sir, and you speak it like a very Natural.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: I believe you well: now for Dutch:
Ducky de do what heb ye ge brought.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I pray stop your mouth, for I never heard such Dutch before broached.

sp.speaker: Frsc.
sp.p: Nay I think you have not met with no peasant: Hear you M. Mouse, (so your name is I take it) I have considered of your learning in these aforesaid Languages, and find you reasonable: So, so, now this is the matter; Can you take the ease to teach these Tongues to two or three Gentlewomen of mine acquaintance, and I will see you paid for your labour.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Yes sir, and that most willingly.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Why then M. Mouse, to their use, I entertain ye, which had not been but for the troubles of the world, that I myself have no leisure to show my skill: Well sir, if you will please to walk with me, I will bring you to them.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.l: Sit till dinner is done; not I, I swear:
Shall I stay? till he belch into mine ears
Those rustic Phrases, and those Dutch French terms,
Stammering half Sentences dogbolt Eloquence:
And when he hath no love for-sooth, why then
He tells me Cloth is dear at Anwerpe, and the men
Of Amsterdam have lately made a law,
That none but Dutch as he, may traffic there:
Then stands he still and studies what to say;
And after some half hour, because the Ass
Hopes (as he thinks) I shall not contradict him.
He tells me that my Father brought him to me,
And that I must perform my Fathers will.
Well good-man Goose-cap, when thou wooest again,
Thou shalt have simple ease, for thy Loves pain.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Alas poor Wench, I sorrow for thy hap,
To see how thou art clogged with such a Dunce:
Forsooth my Sire hath fitted me far better,
My Frenchman comes upon me with the Sa, sa, sa;
Sweet Madam pardone moye I pray:
And then out goes his Hand, down goes his Head,
Swallows his Spittle, frizzles his Beard; and then to me:
Pardone moy mistresse Mathea,
If I be bold, to mick so bold met you,
Think it go will that spurs me thus up you.
Then cast not off so good and true Lover,
Madama celestura de la, (I know not what)
Do oft pray to God that me would love her:
And then he reckons a catalogue of names
of such as love him, and yet cannot get him.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nay, but your Monsieur is but a Mouse in cheese,
Compared with my Seignior, he can tell
Of Lady Uenus, and her Son blind Cupid:
Of the fair Scilla that was loved of Glaucus,
And yet scorned Glaucus, and yet loved King Minos;
Yet Minos hated her, and yet she helped him;
And yet he scorned her, yet she killed her Father
To do her good; yet he could not abide her:
Nay, he will be bawdy too in his discourse;
And when he is so, he will take my Hand,
And tickle the Palm, wink with his one Eye,
Gape with his Mouth, and

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: And, hold thy tongue I prithee: here is my father.

body.stage: Enter Pisaro, Aluaro, Uandalle, Delion, Haruie, Walgraue, and Heigham.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Unmannerly, untaught, unnurtured Girls,
Do I bring Gentlemen, my very friends
To feast with me, to revel at my House,
That their good likings, may be set on you,
And you like misbehaved and sullen Girls,
Turn tail to such, as may advance your states:
I shall remember it, when you think I do not.
I am sorry Gentlemen, your cheer is no better;
But what did want at Board, excuse me for,
And you shall have amends be made in Bed.
To them friends, to them; they are none but yours:
For you I bred them, for you brought them up:
For you I kept them, and you shall have them:
I hate all others that resort to them:
Then rouse your bloods, be bold with what is your own:
For I and mine (my friends) be yours, or none.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: God-gee god-morrow sir, I have brought you M. Mouse here to teach my young Mistresses: I assure you (for-sooth) he is a brave Frenchman.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Welcome friend, welcome: my man (I think)
Hath at the full, resolved thee of my will.
Monsieur Delion, I pray question him:
I tell you sir, it is only for your sake,
That I do mean to entertain this fellow,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A bots of all ill luck, how came these here?
Now am I exposed except the Wenches help me:
I have no French to flap them in the mouth,

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: To see the luck of a good fellow, poor Anthony
Could never have sorted out a worser time:
Now will the pack of all our sly devises
Be quite laid ope, as one undoes an Oyster:
Francke, Heigham, and mad Ned, fall to your muses,
To help poor Anthony now at a pinch,
Or all our market will be spoiled and marred.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Tut man, let us alone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Monsieur, Vous estes tresbien venu, de quell pais estes vous.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Vous, that is you: sure he says, how do men call you Monsieur le Mouche?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Sister, help sister; that is honest Anthonie,
And he answers, your wooer cuius contrarium.

l.foreign: Monsieur, Vous n'entens pas, Je ne demaunde puit,

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Monsieur Delion, he that made your Shoes, made them not in fashion: they should have been cut square at the toe.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Madam, my Shoe met the square toe, what be that?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why sauce-box, how now you unreverent minx
Why? in whose Stable hast thou been brought up,
To interrupt a man in midst of speech?
Monsieur Delion, disquiet not yourself,
But as you have begun, I pray proceed
To question with this Countryman of yours.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: That me shall do tres beien, but the bella Madonna the iune Gentlewoman do show some singe of amour to speak lot me, epurce monsieur, me shall say but two tree four five word to this francois: or sus Monsieur Le mouche en quelle partie de Fraunce esties vous ne?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Fraunce.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Ned.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'sblood, let me come.
Master Pisaro, we have occasion of affairs,
Which calls us hence with speed; wherefore I pray
Defer this business till some fitter time,
And to perform what at the Exchange we spoke of.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A blessing on that tongue, saith Anthony.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry Gentlemen, I will, I will.
Aluaro to your task, fall to your task,
I will bear away those three, who being here,
Would set my Daughters on a merry pin:
Then cheerly try your lucks; but speak, and speed,
For you alone (say I) shall do the deed.

body.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Haruy, Walgraue, and Higham.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Hear you M. Mouse, did you dine today at Paules with the rest of the Gentlemen there?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: No sir, I am yet undined.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Methinks you should have a reasonable good
stomach then by this time, as for me I can sell nothing within me from my mouth to my Codpiece but all Empty, wherefore I think a piece of wisdom to go in and see what Maudelin hath provided for our Dinner master Mouse will you go in?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: With as good a stomach and desire as yourself.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Let us pass in then

sp.speaker: Uanda.
sp.p: Han seg you Dochtor, vor what cause, voer why bede also much grooterlie strange, O seg you what, if that ghy speake to me, is dattghy loue me.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.p: Is it that I care not for you, is it that your breath stinks, if that your breath stinks not, you must learn sweeter English or I shall never understand your suite.

sp.speaker: Delion.
sp.l: Pardone moy Madame.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: With all my heart so you offend no more.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Is that an offence to be amorous di one belle Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I sir see your Belle Gentle-woman cannot be amorous of you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then if I were as that belle Gentlewoman's lover,
I would trouble her no further, nor be amorous any longer.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: Madonna yet the Belleza of the face beauty deform of all the Corpo may be such that no danger, nor all the bad chance, can make him leave her dulce visage.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: But seignior Aluaro if the danger or bad chance were such, that she should love and live with another, then the dulce visage must be left in spite of the lovers teeth, whilst he may whine at his own ill fortune.

sp.speaker: Uanda.
sp.p: Datts waer matresse, for it is vntrue saying, they wint he taught they verleift lie scrat sin gatt .

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: And I think to are like too scratch there but never to claw any of my Sisters love away.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Then shall your sister do against her father's will,
for your father segt that I shall have her for mine wife.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: I think not so sir, for I never heard him say so but I will go in and ask him if his meaning be so.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Hark sister seignior Aluaro saith, that I am the fairest of all us three,

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Believe him not for he will tell any lie.
If so he thinks thou mayst be pleased thereby,
Come go with me and never stand prating here,
I have a jest to tell thee in thine ear,
Shall make you laugh: come let your seignior stand,
I know there is not a Wench in all this Town,
Scoffs at him more; or loves him less than thou.
Master Uandalle, as much I say for you;
If needs you marry with an English Lass,
Woe her in English, or she will call you Ass.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Tut that is a French cog; sure I think,
There is never a Wench in Fraunce not half so fond,
To woe and sue so for your Monsieurship.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Par may foy Madame, she does think there is no Wench so hard as you: for the Filly was cree dulce, tender, and amorous for me to love her; now me think that I being such a fine man, you should love me.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: So think not I, sir.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: But so thinketh other Demoiselles.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Nay I will lay my love to your command,
That my Sisters think not so: How say you sister Mall?
Why how now Gentlemen, is this your talk?
What beaten in plain field; where be your Maids?
Nay then I see their loving humour fades,
And they resign their interest up to me;
And yet I cannot serve for all you three:
But lest two should be mad, that I love one,
You shall be all alike, and I will love none:
The world is scant, when so many Iacke Dawes,
Hover about one Coarse with greedy paws:
If needs you will have me stay till I am dead,
Carrion for Crows, Mathea for her Ned:
And so farewell, we Sisters do agree,
To have our wills, but never to have you three.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Madama attendez, Madama: is she alle? do she mockque de nows in such sort?

p.foreign: O the pestilence, hoe if datick can neite dese Englese spreake vel, it shall her Fader seg how this is to passe gecomen.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.l: Ne parlate, see here signors the Father.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: Now Friends, now Gentlemen, how speeds your work; have you not found them shrewd unhappy girls?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: Master Pisaro, the Doctor mistress Laurentia call me the Dilly, then Ass, for that I can not english speak.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: And that we shall no speak, that we shall no have them for the wife.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Are they so lusty? Dare they be so proud?
Well, I shall find a time to meet with them:
In the mean season, pray frequent my house.
Ho now sirrah, whither are you running?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: About a little tiny business.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What business, Ass?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Indeed I was not sent to you: and yet I was sent after the three Gen-men that dined here, to bid them come to our house at ten o'clock at night, when you were abed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, what is this? Can this be true?
What, art thou sure the Wenches bade them come?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: So they said, unless their minds be changed since: for a Woman is like a Weathercock they say, and I am sure of no more than I am certain of: but I will go in and bid them send you word, whether they shall come or no.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: No sirrah, stay you here; but one word more:
Did they appoint the come one by one, or else all together?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Altogether: Lord that such a young man as you should have no more wit: why if they should come together, one could not make room for them, but coming one by one, they will stand there if there were twenty of them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: How this news glads me, and revives my soul: How say you sirs, what will you have a jest worth the telling; nay worth the acting: I have it Gentlemen, I have it Friends.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Seignior Pisaro, I prey de gratia what manner shall we have? what will the parler? what bon do you know Seignior Pisaro, dichetinoi signor Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: O that youth so sweet, so soon should turn to age; were I as you, why this were sport alone for me to do.
sp.l: Hark ye, hark ye; here my man,
Saith, that the Girls have sent for Master Heigham
And his two friends, I know they love them dear,
And therefore wish them late at night be here
To revel with them: Will you have a jest,
To work my will, and give your longings rest:
Why then M. Uandalle, and you two,
Shall soon at midnight come, as they should do,
And court the Wenches; and to be unknown,
And taken for the men, whom they alone
So much affect; each one shall change his name:
Master Uandalle, you shall take Heigham, and you
Young Haruie, and monsieur Delion Ned,
And under shadows, he of substance sped:
How like you this device? how think you of it?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: O the brave the galliard devise: me shall come by the night and contier fair the Anglois Gentlehomes dictenous ainsi monsieur Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You are in the right sir.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: And I shall name me the seignior Haruy, and monsieur Delion shall be depiculo seignior Ned, and when madonna Laurentia shall say, who be there? mister Vandalle shall say, O my sweet Lady, here be your love Maestro Heigham: Is no this the bravissimo, master Vandalle!

l.foreign: Slaet up den tromele, vanick shall come
Vp to de camerken, wan my new Wineken
Slaet up den tromele, van I shall come.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, master Vandalle,
I trow you will be merry soon at night,
When you shall do in deed, what now you hope of.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: I shall v seg father, I shall teach your Daughter such a ting, make her laugh too.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well my Sons all, (for so I count you shall)
What we have here devised, provide me for:
But above all, do not (I pray) forget
To come but one by one, as they did wish.

p.foreign: Mar hortens vader, I veite neite de wecke to your houis, hort ens shall maister Frisco your manneken come to calle de me, and bring me to vhouse.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry shall he: see that you be ready,
And at the hour of eleven gong at night:
Hie you to Bucklersburie to his Chamber,
And so direct him straight unto my house:
My Son Aluaro, and monsieur Delion,
I know, doth know the way exceeding well:
Well, we will to the Rose in Barken for an hour:
And sirrah Frisco, see you prove no blab.

body.stage: Exeunt Pisaro, Aluaro, Delion, and Uandalle.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
O monstrous, who would think my Master had so much wit in his old rotten budget: and yet i'faith he is not much troubled with it neither. Why what wise man in a kingdom would send me for the Dutchman? Does he think I will not cozen him: O fine, I will
have the bravest sport: O brave, I will have the gallantest sport: O come; now if I can hold behind, while I may laugh a while, I care not: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Why how now Frisco, why laughest thou so heartily?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Laugh M. Mouse: Laugh, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Laugh, why should I laugh? or why art thou so merry?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O master Mouse, master Mouse, it would make any Mouse, Rat, Cat, or Dog, laugh to think, what sport we shall have at our house soon at night: I will tell you, all, my young Mistresses sent me after M. Heigham and his friends, to pray them come to our house after my old Master was a bed: Now I went, and I went; and I run, and I went: and whom should I meet, but my Master and M. Pisaro and the Strangers; so my Master very worshipfully (I must needs say) examined me whither I went now? I durst not tell him an untruth, for fear of lying, but told him plainly and honestly mine errand: Now who would think my Master had such a monstrous plaguey wit, he was as glad as could be; out of all scotch and notch glad, out of all count glad? and so sirrah he bid the three Uplandish-men come in their steads and woe my young Mistresses: Now it made me so laugh to think how they will be cozened, that I could not follow my Master: But I will follow him, I know he is gone to the Tavern in his merry humour: Now if you will keep this as secret as I have done hitherto, we shall have the bravest sport soon, as can be. I must be gone, say nothing.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well, it is so:
And we will have good sport, or it shall go hard;
This must the Wenches know, or all is maid.
Hark you Mis. Moll, Mis. Laurentia, Mis. Matt,
I have such news (my Girls) will make you smile.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: What be they Master, how I long to hear it?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: A Woman right, still longing, and with child,
For everything they hear, or light upon:
Well, if you be mad Wenches, hear it now,
Now may your knaveries give the deadliest blow
To night-walkers, cauese-droppers, or outlandish love,
That ever was struck.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Anthony Mowche,
Move but the matter; tell us but the jest,
And if you find us slack to execute,
Never give credence, or believe us more.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Then know: The Strangers your Outlandish loves,
Appointed by your Father, comes this night
Instead of Haruie, Heigham, and young Ned,
Under their shadows to get to your bed:
For Frisco simply told him why he went:
I need not to instruct, you can conceive,
You are not Stocks nor Stones, but have some store
Of wit and knavery too.

sp.speaker: Mathæ.
sp.l: Anthony, thanks
Is too too small a guerdon for this news;
You must be English: Well sir seignior souse,
I will teach you tricks for coming to our house.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Are you so crafty, o that night were come,
That I might hear my Dutchman how he would swear
In his own mother Language, that he loves me:
Well, if I quit him not, I here pray God,
I may lead Apes in Hell, and die a Maid;
And that were worser to me than a hanging.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Well said old honest huddles; here is a heap
Of merry Lasses: Well, for myself,
I will hie me to your Lovers, bid them mark
With us at night, and in some corner stay
Near to our house, where they may make some play
Upon your rivals, and when they are gone,
Come to your windows.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Do so good Master.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Peace, begone; for this our sport,
Somebody soon will mourn.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How favourable Heaven and Earth is seen,
To grace the mirthful complot that is laid,
Nights Candles burn obscure, and the pale Moon
Favouring our drift, lies buried in a Cloud:
I can but smile to see the simple Girls,
Hoping to have their sweethearts here tonight,
Tickled with extreme joy, laugh in my face:
But when they find, the Strangers in their steads,
They will change their note, and sing another song.
Where be these Girls here? what, to bed, to bed:
Mawdlin make fast the Doors, rake up the Fire;
Gods me, it is nine o'clock, hark Bow-bell rings:
Some look down below, and see who knocks:
And hark you Girls, settle your hearts at rest,
And full resolve you, that tomorrow morn,
You must be wed to such as I prefer;
I mean Aluaro and his other friends:
Let me no more be troubled with your nays.
You shall do what I will have, and so resolve.
Welcome M. Moore, welcome,
What wind in God's name drives you forth so late?

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Faith sir, I am come to trouble you,
My wife this present night is brought to bed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: To bed, and what hath God sent you?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: A jolly Girl, sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And God bless her: But what is your will sir?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Faith sir, my house being full of Friends,
Such as (I thank them) came to see my wife?
I would request you, that for this one night,
My daughter Susan might be lodged here.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lodge in my house, welcome with all my heart,
Matt hark you, she shall lie with you,
Trust me she could not come in fitter time.
For hear you sir, tomorrow in the morning,
All my three Daughters must be married,
Good master Moore let us have your company,
What say you sir; Welcome honest friend.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: How now sirrah what is the news with you?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Mowche hear you, stir betimes tomorrow,
For then I mean your Scholars shall be wed:
What news, what news man that you look so sad,

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: He brings me word my wife is new fallen sick,
And that my daughter cannot come tonight:
Or if she does, it will be very late.

sp.speaker: Pisa,
sp.l: Believe me I am then more sorry for it.
But for your daughter come she soon or late,
Some of us will be up to let her in,
For here be three means not to sleep tonight:
Well you must be gone? commend me to your wife,
Take heed how you go down, the stairs are bad,
Bring here a light.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: It is well I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Good night master Moore farewell honest friend,
Come, come to bed, to bed it is nine and past,
Do not stand prating here to make me fetch you,
But get you to your Chambers.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: By our lady here is short work, hark you Girls,
Will you tomorrow marry with the strangers.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: I'faith sir no I will first leap out at window,
Before Marina marry with a stranger,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Yes but your father swears, you shall have one.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes but his daughters, swears they shall have none,
These whoreson Cannibals, these Philistines,
These tango mongoes shall not rule Over me,
I will have my will and Ned, or I will have none.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: How will you get him? how will you get him?
I know no other way except it be this,
That when your father is in his soundest sleep,
You ope the Door and run away with them,

sp.speaker: All sisters.
sp.l: So we will rather than miss of them.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: It is well resolved i'faith and like yourselves,
But hear you? to your Chambers presently,
Lest that your father do descry our drift,
Mistress Susan should come but she cannot,
Nor perhaps shall not, yet perhaps she shall,
Might not a man conceive a pretty jest?
And make as mad a Riddle as this is,
If all things fadge not, as all things should do,
We shall be sped i'faith, Matt shall have hue.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Were be you master Frisco.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Here sir, here sir, now if I could cozen him, take heed sir here is a post.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: I be so groterly hot, that I sweat, O when shall we come there.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Be you so hot sir, let me carry your Cloak, I assure you it will ease you much.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: There here, there, it is so Dark eye cannot see.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Aye so so: now you may travel in your Hose and Doublet: now look I as like the Dutchman, as if I were spit out of his mouth: I will straight home, and speak good and brood, and toot and gibberish; and in the dark I will have a fling at the Wenches. Well, I say no more; farewell M. Mendall, I must go seek my fortune.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p:
Master Frisco, master Frisco, what shall you no speak; make you the Fool? Why master Frisco; O the skellum,
he be ga met de Cloake, me shall seg his mester, han mester Frisco, waer sidy mester Frisco .

sp.speaker: Haruy.
sp.l: Goes the case so well seignior bottle-nose?
It may be we shall overreach your drift;
This is the time the Wenches sent us word
Our bombast Dutchman and his mates will come.
Well neat Italian, you must don my shape:
Play your part well, or I may haps pay you.
What, speechless Ned? faith whereon musest thou?
It is on your French corival, for my life:
He come ete vostre, and so forth,
Till he hath foisted in a Brat or two?
How then, how then?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'swounds I will geld him first,
Ere that infestatious losel revel there.
Well Matt, I think thou knowest what Ned can do;
Shouldest thou change Ned for Noddy, me for him,
Thou didst not know thy loss, i'faith thou didst not.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come leave this idle chat, and let us provide
Which of us shall be scar-crow to these Fools,
And set them out the way?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Why that will I.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Then put a Sword into a mad-mans hand:
Thou art so hasty, that but cross thy humour,
And thou wilt be ready cross them over the pates:
Therefore for this time, I will supply the room.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: And so we shall be sure of chit enough;
You will hold them with your flouts and gulls so long,
That all the night will scarcely be enough
To put in practise, what we have devised:
Come, come, I will be the man shall do the deed.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Well, I am content to save your longing.
But soft, where are we? Ha, here is the house,
Come let us take our stands: Fraunce stand you there,
And Ned and I will cross the other side.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Do so: But hush, I hear one passing hither.

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.p: O the favourable aspect of the heaven, it is so obscure, so dark, so black that no mortal creature can know de me: I pray a Dio I shall have the right Wench: Ah si I be reached, here be the house of seignior Pisaro, I shall have the madonna Marina, and daruor I shall knock to the door.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a pox are you mad or drunk;
What, do you mean to break my Glasses?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: What be that Glass? What drunk, what mad?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: What Glasses sir; why my Glasses: and if you be so crank, I will call the Constable; you will not enter into a man's house (I hope) in spite of him?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Nor durst you be so bold as to stand there,
If once the Master of the House did know it.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Is this your House? be you the Seignior of this Casa?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: Seignior me no signors, nor Casa me no casas: but get you hence, or you are like to taste of the Bastinado.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Do, do, good Ferdinand, pummel the loggerhead.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Is this not the House of master Pisaro?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Yes marry when? can you tell: how do you?
I thank you heartily, my finger in your mouth.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: What be that?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry that you are an Ass and a Loggerhead,
To seek master Pisaros house here.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: I prey de gratia, what be this place?
What do ye call this street?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What sir; why Leaden-hall, could you not see the four Spouts as you came along?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Certenemento Leden hall, I hit my head by the way, there may be the voer Spouts: I prey de gratia, which be the way to Crochefriers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: How, to Croched-friers? Marry you must go along till you come to the Pump, and then turn on your right hand.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Seignior, adieu.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Farewell and be hanged Seignior:
Now for your fellow, if the Ass would come.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: By my trot me do so much think of this Gentlewoman the fine wench, that me think each hover ten day, and each day ten year, till I come to her: Here be the house of sin father, fall awl and knock.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What a bots ail you, are you mad?
Will you run over me and break my Glasses?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Glasses, what Glasses? Prey is monsieur Pisaro to the mason?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Hark Ned, there is thy substance

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay by the Mass, the substance is here,
The shadow is but an Ass.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What Master Pisaro?
Loggerhead, here is none of your Pisaros?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Yes but this is the house of master Pisaro.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Will not this monsieur Motley take his answer?
I will go and knock the ass about the pate.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay by your leave sir, but I will hold your worship.
This sturre we should have had, had you stood there.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Why, would it not vex one to hear the ass,
Stand prating here of dit and dan, and den and dog?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: One of thy mettle Ned, would surely do it:
But peace, and hark to the rest.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Do no the fine Gentlewoman mistress Mathea dwell in this place?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.p: No sir, here dwells none of your fine Gentle-woman: It were a good deed sirrah, to see who you are;
sp.l: You come hither to steal my Glasses.
And then counterfeit you are going to your Queans.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: I be deceived this dark night; here be no wench, I be no in the right place: I prey Monsieur, what be name this Street, and which be the way to Croshe-friers?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Marry this is Fauchurch-streete,
And the best way to Crotched-friers, is to follow your nose

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.p: Uanshe, street, how chance me come to Vanshe street? well monsieur, me must awl to Croche-friers.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Farewell fortipence, go seek your Seignior,
I hope you will find yourselves two Dolts anon:
Hush Fredinand, I hear the last come stamping hither.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Ha sirrah, I have left my fat Dutchman, and run myself almost out of breath too: now to my young mistresses go I, somebody cast an old shoe after me: but soft, how shall I do to counterfeit the Dutchman, because I speak English so like a natural; Tush, take you no thought for that, let me alone for Squintum squantum: soft, here is my Masters house,

sp.speaker: High.
sp.l: Who is there.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Who is there, why sir here is: Nay that is too good English; Why here be the growtte Dutchman.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Then there is not only a growte head, but an Ass also.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: What be you, you be an English Ox to call a gentle moan Ass.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Hark Ned yonder is good greeting.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: But you, if you be Master Mouse that dwell here, tell your mistress Laurentia that her sweet heart Master Vandal would speak with her,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Master Mendall, get you gone, lest you get a broken Pate and so mar all: here is no entrance for mistress Laurentios sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Gods sacaren what is the luck now.
Shall not I come to my friend master Pisar House?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Yes and to master Pisaros Shoes too, if he or they were here.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Why my great friend, M. Pisaro doth dwell here.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Sirrah, you lie, here dwells nobody but I, that have dwelt here this one and forty years, and sold Glasses.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Lie farther, one and fifty at the least.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Hoo, hoo, hoo; do you give the Gentleman the lie?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Aye sir, and will give you a lick of my Cudgel, if ye stay long and trouble the whole street with your bawling: hence dolt, and go seek M. Pisaros House.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Go seek M. Pisaros House;
Where shall I go seek it?

sp.speaker: Hegh.
sp.l: Why, you shall go seek it where it is.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: That is here in Crodched-friers.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: How Loggerhead, is Croched-friers here?
I thought you were some such drunken Ass,
That come to seek Croched-friers in Tower-streete:
But get you along on your left hand, and be hanged;
You have kept me out of my Bed with your bangling,
A good while longer than I would have been.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Ah, ah, How is this? Is not this Croched-friers? Tell me, I will hold a Crown they gave me so much Wine at the Tavern, that I am drunk, and know not on it.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: My dutchman is out his Compass and his Card;
He is reckoning what Wind hath drove him hither:
I will swear he thinks never to see Pisaros.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay it is so, I am sure drunk: Soft let me see, what was I about? O now I have it, I must go to my Masters house and counterfeit the Dutchman, and get my young Mistress: well, and I must turn on my left hand, for I have forgot the way quite and clean:
sp.l: Fare thee well good friend, I am a simple Dutchman I.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Fair weather after you. And now my Lads,
Have I not played my part as I should do?

sp.speaker: Haru.
