sp.l: It was well, it was well: But now let us cast about,
To set these Woodcocks farther from the House,
And afterwards return unto our Girls.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Content, content; come, come make haste.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: I go and turn, and then I come to this place, I can no tell where, and shall do I can no tell what, turn by the Pump; I pump it fair.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Me awl, and awl and can no come to Croche-friers.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O miserable Black-pudding, if I can tell which is the way to my Masters house, I am a Red-herring, and no honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Who spoke there?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Who be there? who awl there?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: How is this? For my life here are the Strangers: O that I had the Dutchmans Hose, that I might creep into the Pockets; they will all three fall upon me and beat me.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Who do there ander?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Amiss?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O brave; it is nobody but M. Pharoo and the Frenchman going to our House, on my life: well, I will have some sport with them, if the Watch hinder me not.
sp.l: Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Who parley there, in what place, in what street be you?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Why sir, I can tell where I am; I am in Tower-streete; Where a Devil be you?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: I be here in Lede-hall.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: In Leaden-hall? I trow I shall meet with you anon: in Leaden-hall? What a simple Ass is this Frenchman. Some more of this: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Moi I be here in Vanshe-streete.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: This is excellent i'faith, as fit as a Fiddle: I in Tower-streete, you in Leaden-hall, and the third in Fanchurch-streete; and yet all three hear one another, and all three speak together: either we must be all three in Leaden-hall, or all three in Tower-streete, or all three in Fanchurch-streete; or all three Fools.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Monsieur Gentle-home, can you well teach the way to Croshe-frier?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: How to Croched-friers? Aye aye sir, passing well if you will follow me.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: I that me shall monsieur Gentle-home, and give you tanks.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: And monsieur Pharo, I shall lead you such a jaunt, that you shall scarce give me thanks for. Come sirs follow me: now for a dirty Puddle, the pissing Condit, or a great Post, that might turn these two from Asses to Oxen by knocking their Horns to their Fore-heads.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Where be thee now seignior?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Even where you will seignior, for I know not:
Soft I smell: O pure Nose.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: What do you smell?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I have the scent of London-stone as full in my nose, as Abchurch-lane of mother Walls Pasties: sirs feel about, I smell London-stone.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: What be this?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Soft let me see; feel I should say, for I cannot see:
O lads pray for my life, for we are almost at Croched-friers.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: That is good: but what be this Post?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: This Post; why it is the May-pole on Iuie-bridge going to Westminster.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Ho Wesmistere, how come we to Wesmistere?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Why on your Legs fools, how should you go? Soft, here is another: O now I know indeed where I am; we are now at the farthest end of Shoredich, for this is the May-pole.

sp.speaker: Delo.
sp.p:
Sordiche; O dio, there be some native tinge, some
Spirit do lead us.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: You say true sir, for I am afeared your French spirit is up so far already, that you brought me this way, because you would find a Charm for it at the Blue Bore in the Spittle: But soft, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Maids in your Smocks, look well to your Locks,
Your Fire and your Light; and God give you good night.

sp.speaker: Delia.
sp.l: Monsieur Gentle-home, I prey parley one, too, tree, fore, words for us to this old man.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Yes marry shall I sir. I pray honest Fellow, in what Street be we?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Ho Frisco, whither frisk you at this time of night?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: What, Monsieur Frisco?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Seignior Frisco?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: The same, the same: Hark ye honesty, metihnks you might do well to have an M. under your Girdle, considering how Seignior Pisaro, and this other Monsieur do hold of me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O sir, I cry you mercy; pardon this fault, and I will do as much for you the next time.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Well, passing over superfluous talk, I pray what Street is this; for it is so dark, I know not where I am?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why art thou drunk, Dost thou not know Fanchurch-streete?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Aye sir, a good Fellow may sometimes be overseen among Friends; I was drinking with my Master and these Gentlemen, and therefore no marvel though I be none of the wisest at this present: But I pray thee Goodman Buttericke, bring me to my Masters House.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why I will, I will, push that you are so strange now adays: but it is an old said saw, Honours change Manners.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Good-man Buttericke will you walk afore:
Come honest Friends, will ye go to our House?

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Oui monsieur Frisco.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Si seignior Frisco.

p.foreign: O the skellam Frisco, I weit not where that I be, I goe and hit my nose op this post, and I goe and hit my nose op danden post; O the villaine: Well, where bon I now? Haw laet syen is dut not croshe vrier, ya seker so ist and dit M. Pisaros huis: O the good shaunce, well I shall now have the Wenshe Laurentia, mestris Laurentia.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Who is there, Master Haruie?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Master Walgraue?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Master Heigham?

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Ya my Lou, here be master Heigham your good friend.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: How, Master Heigham my great friend?
Out alas, is one of the Strangers.

sp.speaker: Lauren.
sp.p: Peace you Mammet, let us see which it is; we may chance teach him a strange trick for his learning: M. Heigham, what wind drives you to our house so late?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: O my lief Mesken, the love tolv be so good, that it bring me out my bed for you.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.p: Ha, ha, we know the Ass by his ears; it is the Dutchman: what shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.p: Peace, let him not know, that you are here: M. Heigham, if you will stay awhile that I may see, if my Father be asleep, and I will make means we may come together

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.p: That shall I my Love. Is this no well counterfeit I speak so like master Heigham as it is possible.

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.l: Well, what shall we do with this Lubber?
(Lover I should say.)

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: What shall we do with him?
Why crown him with a ~~

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p:
Fie Slut: No, we will use him cleanlier; you know we have never a Sign at the door, would not the jest prove
currant, to make the Dutchman supply that want.

sp.speaker: Laure.
sp.l: Nay, the fool will cry out, and so wake my father.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Why, then we will cut the Rope and cast him down.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: And so jest out a hanging; let us rather draw him up in the Basket, and so starve him to death this frosty night.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.p: In sadness, well advised: Sister, do you hold him in talk, and we will provide it whilst.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Go to then. M. Heigham, o sweet M Higham, doth my Father think that his unkindness can part you and poor Laurentia? No, no, I have found a drift to bring you to my Chamber, if you have but the heart to venture it.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Ventre, shall I go to the see, and be the see, and over the see and in the see for my sweet Lou.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.p: Then you there go into a Basket; for I know no other means to enjoy your company, than so: for my Father hath the Keys of the Door.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Shall I climb up to you? shall I fly up to you? shall I, what segdy?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Bid him do it Sister, we shall see his cunning.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: O no, so you may catch a fall. There M. Heigham,
Put yourself into that Basket, and I will draw you up:
But no words I pray you, for fear my Sister hear you.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: No, no; no word: O the sweet wench, I come,
I come.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Are you ready master Heigham?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Yes I my sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Merrily then my Wenches.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: How heavy the Ass is: Master Heigham, is there any in the Basket but yourself?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: No, no, there be no man.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Are you up sir?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nor never are you like to climb more higher:
Sisters, the Woodcock is caught, the Fool is caged.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: My sweet Lady I be nuc not up, pull me to v.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: When can you tell; what master Uandalle,
A weather-beaten soldier an old whenever,
Thus to be over-reached by three young Girls:
Ah sirrah now we will brag with Mistress Moore,
To have as fine a Parrot as she hath,
Look sisters what a pretty fool it is:
What a green greasy shining Coat he hath,
An Almond for Parrot, a Rope for Parrot.

sp.speaker: Uand.
sp.l: Do you mock que me seger seger,
I shall seg your father.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Do and you there, you see here is your fortune,
Disquiet not my father; if you do,
I will send you with a vengeance to the ground,
Well we must confess we trouble you,
And over-watching makes a wise man mad,
Much more a fool, there is a Cushion for you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To bore you through the nose.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: To lay your head on.
Couch in your Kennel sleep and fall to rest,
And so good night for London maids scorn still,
A Dutch-man should be seen to curb their will.

p.foreign: Hort ye Daughter, hort ye? gods se ker kin? will ye no let me come to you? I bid you let me come to you what salick don, I woud not for vn hundred pounde Aluaro and Delion , should seeme ope this maner, well what shall I don, I mout not cal: for the Wenshes will cut the rope and breake my necke; I shall here bleauen til the morning, and then I shall cal to mester Pisaro, and make him shafe and strite his dauctors: O the skellum Frisco, O des cruell Hores.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I will put the Light out, lest I be espied,
For closely I have stolen me forth a-doors,
That I might know, how my three Sons have sped.
Now (afore God) my heart is passing light,
That I have overreached the Englishmen:
Ha, ha, Master Uandalle, many such nights
Will swage your big swollen bulk, and make it lank:
When I was young; yet though my Hairs be gray,
I have a Young man's spirit to the death,
And can as nimbly trip it with a Girl,
As those which fold the spring-tide in their Beards:
Lord how the very thought of former times,
Supplies these near dried limbs with activeness:
Well, thoughts are shadows, sooner lost than seen,
Now to my Daughters, and their merry night,
I hope Aluaro and his company,
Have read to them moral Philosophy,
And they are full with it: Here I will stay,
And tarry till my gallant youths come forth.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: You mad-man, wild-oats, mad-cap, where art thou?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Here afore.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: O ware what love is? Ned hath found the scent;
And if the Cony chance to miss her Borough,
She is over-borne i'faith, she cannot stand it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I know that voice, or I am much deceived.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come, why loiter we? this is the Door:
But soft, here is one asleep.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Come, let me feel:
O it is some Rogue or other; spurn him, spurn him.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Be not so wilful, prithee let him lie.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Come back, come back, for we are past the house,
Yonder is Matheas Chamber with the light.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Well fare a head, or I had been descried.
Gods me, what make the Youngsters here so late?
I am a Rouge, and spurn him: well lack sauce,
The Rogue is waking yet, to mar your sport.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Matt, Mistress Mathea; where be these Girls?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Who is there below?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Thy Ned, kind Ned, thine honest trusty Ned.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: No, no, it is the Frenchman in his stead,
That Monsieur motlicoate that can dissemble:
Hear you Frenchman, pack to your Whores in Fraunce;
Though I am Portingale by the Fathers side,
And therefore should be lustful, wanton, light;
Yet goodman Goosecap, I will let you know,
That I have so much English by the Mother,
That no base slavering French shall make me stoop:
And so, sir Dandelion fare you well.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What speechless, not a word: why how now Ned?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The Wench hath taken him down,
He hangs his head.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: You Dandelion, you that talk so well:
Hark you a word or two good Mistress Matt,
Did you appoint your Friends to meet you here,
And being come, tell us of Whores in Fraunce,
A Spanish linnet, and an English Mare,
A Mongrel, half a Dog and half a Bitch;
With Tran-dido, Dil-dido, and I know not what?
Hear you, if you will run away with Ned,
And be content to take me as you find me,
Why so law, I am yours: if otherwise,
You will change your Ned, to be a Frenchman's Trull?
Why then, Madame Delion, Ie vous lassera a Dio, et la bon fortune.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: That voice assures me, that it is my Love:
Say truly, Art thou my Ned? art thou my Love?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'swounds who should I be but Ned?
You make me swear.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Who speak you to? Mathea who is below?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Marina.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Young master Haruy? for that voice saith so.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Speak sister Matt, is not my true Love there?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Ned is.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Not master Heigham?

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Laurentia, here.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: i'faith thou art welcome.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Better cannot Fall.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Sweet, so art thou.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: As much to mine.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Nay Gentles, welcome all.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Here is cunning harlotry, they feed these off
With welcome, and kind words, whilst other Lads
Revel in that delight they should possess:
Good Girls, I promise you I like you well.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Say master Haruy, saw you, as you came,
That Lecher, which my Sire appoints my man;
I mean that wanton base Italian,
That Spanish-leather spruce companion:
That antic Ape tricked up in fashion?
Had the Ass come, I would learn him, difference been
Betwixt an English Gentleman and him.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: How would you use him (sweet).
If he should come?

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Nay nothing (sweet) but only wash his crown:
Why the Ass woos in such an amorous key,
That he presumes no Wench should say him nay:
He slavers not his Fingers, wipes his Bill,
And swears i'faith you shall, i'faith I will;
That I am almost mad to bide his wooing.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Look what he said in word, I will act in doing.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Leave thought of him, for day steals on apace,
And to our Loves: Will you perform your words;
All things are ready, and the Parson stands,
To join as hearts in hearts, our hands in hands;
Night favours us, the thing is quickly done,
Then truss up bag and Baggages, and be gone:
And ere the morning, to augment your joys,
We will make you mothers of six goodly Boys.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Promise them three good Ned, and say no more.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: But I will get three, and if I get not four.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: There is a sound Card at Maw, a lusty lad,
Your father thought him well, when one he had,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: What say you sweets, will you perform your words?

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Love to true love, no lesser meed affords?
We say we love you, and that loves fair breath
Shall lead us with you round about the Earth:
And that our loves, vows, words, may all prove true,
Prepare your Arms, for thus we fly to you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: This works like wax, now ere tomorrow day,
If you two ply it but as well as I,
We will work our lands out of Pisaros Daughters:
And cancel all our bonds in their great Bellies,
When the slave knows it, how the Rogue will curse.

sp.speaker: Matt.
sp.l: Sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Matt.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: Where art thou.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Mathe.
sp.l: O Iesus here is our father.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: The Devil he is.

sp.speaker: Haru
sp.l: Master Pisaro, twenty times God morrow.

sp.speaker: Pisa,
sp.l: Good morrow? now I tell you Gentlemen.
You wrong and move my patience overmuch,
What will you Rob me, Kill me, Cut my Throat:
And set mine own blood here against me too,
You housewives? Baggages? or what is worse,
Wilful, stubborn, disobedient:
Use it not Gentlemen, abuse me not,
Newgate hath room, there is law enough in England,

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Be not so testy, hear what we can say.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Will you be win'de? first learn to keep a wife,
Learn to be thrift, learn to keep your Lands,
And learn to pay your debts too, I advise, else.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What else, what Lands, what Debts, what will you do?
Have you not Land in Mortgage for your money,
Nay since it is so, we owe you not a Penny,
Fret not, Fume not, never bend the Brow:
You take Ten in the hundred more than Law,
We can complain, extortion, simony,
Newgate hath Room, there is Law enough in England.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Prithee have done.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Prithee me no Prithees.
Here is my wife, 'sblood touch her, if thou darest,
Hearst thou, I will lie with her before thy face,
Against the Cross in Cheap, here, any where,
What you old crafty Fox you.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Ned, stop there.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Nay, nay speak out, bear witness Gentlemen,
Where is Mowche, charge my Musket, bring me my Bill,
For here are some that mean to Rob thy master.
I am a Fox with you, well Iack sauce,
Beware lest for a Goose, I pray on you.
In baggages, Mowche make fast the door.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: A vengeance on ill luck,

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: What never storm,
But bridle anger with wise government.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: Whom? Anthony our friend, Ah now our hopes,
Are found too light to balance our ill haps.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Tut never say so, for Anthony
Is not devoid of means to help his Friends.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: 'swounds, what a devil made he forth so late
I will lay my life it was he that feigned to sleep,
And we all unsuspicious, termed a Rogue:
O God, had I but known him; if I had,
I would have writ such Letters with my Sword
Upon the bald skin of his parching pate,
That he should never have lived to cross us more.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: These menaces are vain, and helpeth naught:
But I have in the depth of my conceit
Found out a more material stratagem:
Hark Master Walgraue, yours craves quick dispatch,
About it straight, stay not to say farewell.
You Master Heigham, hie you to your Chamber,
And stir not forth, my shadow, or myself,
Will in the morning early visit you;
Build on my promise sir, and good night.
Last, yet as great in love, as to the first:
If you remember, once I told a jest,
How feigning to be sick, a Friend of mine
Possessed the happy issue of his Love:
That counterfeited humour must you play;
I need not to instruct, you can conceive,
Use master Brown your Host, as chief in this:
But first, to make the matter seem more true,
Sickly and sadly bid the churl good night;
I hear him at the Window, there he is.
Now for a trick to overreach the Devil.
I tell you sir, you wrong my master much,
And then to make amends, you give hard words:
He hath been a friend to you; nay more, a Father:
I promise you, it is most ungently done.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Aye well said Mouche, now I see thy love,
And thou shalt see mine, one day if I live.
None but my Daughters sir, hangs for your tooth:
I would rather see them hanged first, ere you get them.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, hear a dead man speak,
Who singes the woeful accents of his end.
I do confess I love; then let not love
Prove the sad engine of my lives remove:
Marinaes rich Possession was my bliss?
Then in her loss, all joy eclipsed is:
As every Plant takes virtue of the Sun;
So from her Eyes, this life and being sprung:
But now debarred of those clear shining Rays,
Death for Earth gapes, and Earth to Death obeys:
Each word thou spokest, (o speak not so again)
Bore Deaths true image on the Word engraven;
Which as it flue mixed with Heavens airy breath,
Summoned the dreadful Sessions of my death:
I leave thee to thy wish, and may the event
Prove equal to thy hope and hearts content.
Marina to that hap, that happiest is;
My Body to the Grave, my Soul to bliss.
Have I done well?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Excellent well in troth.

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.l: Aye go; Aye go: your words move me as much,
As doth a Stone being cast against the air.
But soft, What Light is that? What Folks be those? O it is
Aluaro and his other Friends, I will down and let them in.

body.stage: Enter Belman, Frisco, Vandalle, Delion, & Aluaro.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Where are we now gaffer Buttericke?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: Why know you not Croched-friers, where be your wits?

sp.speaker: Aluar.
sp.l: What be this Crosh-viers? vidite padre there; take you that, me shall trouble you no far.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.l: I thank you Gentlemen, good night:
Good night Frisco.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Farewell Buttericke, what a Clown it is:
Come on my masters merrily, I will knock at the door.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Who is there, our three wise Wooers,
Blockhead our man? had he not been,
They might have hanged themselves,
For any Wenches they had hit upon:
Good morrow, or good den, I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Delio.
sp.l: Monsieur de Mowche, what mick you out the House so late?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What, what, young men and sluggards? fie for shame
You trifle time at home about vain toys,
Whilst others in the mean time, steal your Brides:
I tell you sir, the English Gentlemen
Had well-nigh mated you, and me, and all;
The Doors were open, and the Girls abroad,
Their Sweet-hearts ready to receive them too:
And gone forsooth they had been, had not I
(I think by revelation) stopped their flight:
But I have cooped them up, and so will keep them.
But sirrah Frisco, where is the man I sent for?
Whose Cloak have you got there?
How now, where is Uandalle?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: For-sooth he is not here:
Master Mendall you mean, do you not?

sp.speaker: Pisar.
sp.l: Why loggerhead, him I sent for, where is he?
Where hast thou been? How hast thou spent thy time?
Did I not send thee to my Son Vandalle?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Aye M. Mendall; why forsooth I was at his Chamber, and we were coming hitherward, and he was very hot, and bade me carry his Cloak; and I no sooner had it, but he (being very light) firks me down on the left hand, and I turned down on the left hand, and so lost him.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why then you turned together, Ass.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: No sir, we never saw one another since.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why, turned you not both on the left hand?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: No for-sooth we turned both on the left hand.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hoyda, why yet you went both together.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Ah no, we went clean contrary one from another.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why Dolt, why Patch, why Ass,
On which hand turned ye?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Alas, alas, I can not tell for-sooth, it was so dark I could not see, on which hand we turned: But I am sure we turned one way.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Was ever creature plagued with such a Dolt?
My Son Vandalle now hath lost himself;
And shall all night go straying bout the Town;
Or meet with some strange Watch that knows him not;
And all by such an arrant Ass as this.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: No, no, you may soon smell the Dutchmans lodging:
Now for a Figure: Out alas, what is yonder?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.l: Hoyda, hoyda, a Basket: it turns, ho.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Peace ye Villain, and let us see who is there?
Go look about the House; where are our weapons?
What might this mean?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Look, look, look; there is one in it, he peeps out:
Is there never a Stone here to hurl at his Nose.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.p: What, wouldst thou break my Windows with a Stone? How now, who is there, who are you sir?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Look, he peeps out again: O it is M. Mendall, it is M. Mendall: how got he up thither?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What, my Son Vandalle, how comes this to pass?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.l: Seignior Vandalle, what do you go to the wench in the Basket?

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: O Father, Father, here be such cruel Dochterkens, I ben also weary, also weary, also cold; for be in this little Basket: I prey help then.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
He looks like the sign of the Mouth without Bishops gate, gaping, and a great Face, and a great Head,
and no Body.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Son, what have your Adamants
Drawn you up so far, and there left you hanging
Twixt Heaven and Earth like Mahomet's Sepulchre?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: They did unkindly, whosoever they were,
That plagued him here, like Tantalus in Hell,
To touch his Lips like the desired Fruit,
And then to snatch it from his gaping Chaps.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: A little farther seignior Vandalle, and then you may put v head into the window and cash the Wench.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: I prey father that you help: de me, I prey God father.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Help you, but how?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Cut the Rope.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Sir, I will go in and see,
And if I can, I will let him down to you.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Do gentle Mouche: Why but here is a jest;
They say, high climbers have the greatest falls:
If you should fall; as how you will do I know not,
By our lady I should doubt me of my Son:
Pray to the Rope to hold: Art thou there Mouche?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.p: Yes sir, now you may choose, whether you will stay till I let him down, or whether I shall cut him down?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Cut him down master Mowse, cut him down
And let us see, how he will tumble.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why sauce, who asked your counsel?
Let him down.
What, with a Cushion too? why you provided
To lead your life as did Diogines;
And for a Tub, to creep into a Basket.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.p: I shall seg. v father, I came here to your house and spirea's to the Dochterken.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: M. Mendall, you are welcome out of the Basket: I smell a Rated it was not for nothing, that you lost me.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: O skellum, you run away from me.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I thought so sirrah, you gave him the slip.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Faugh, no for-sooth; I will tell you how it was: when we come from Bucklers-Burie into Corn-Wale, and I had taken the Cloak, then you should have turned down on your left hand and so have gone right forward, and so turned up again, and so have crossed the street; and you like an Ass.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why how now Rascal; is your manners such?
You ass, you Dolt, why led you him through Corn-hill,
Your way had been to come through Canning street.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Why so I did sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Why thou seest ye were in Corn-Hill.

sp.speaker: Fris.
sp.p: Indeed sir there was three faults, the Night was dark, Master Mendall drunk, and I sleepy, that we could not tell very well, which way we went.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Sirrah I owe for this a Cudgelling:
But Gentlemen, sith things have fallen out so,
And for I see Uandalle quakes for cold,
This night accept your Lodgings in my house,
And in the morning forward with your marriage,
Come on my sons, sirrah fetch up more wood.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Nay never weep Marina for the matter,
Tears are but signs of sorrow, helping not.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Would it not mad one to be crossed as I,
Being in the very hight of my desire?
The strangers frustrate all: our true love is come,
Nay more, even at the door, and Haruies arms
Spread as a Rainbow ready to receive me,
And then my Father meet us: O God, o God.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: Weep who that list for me, i'faith not I,
Though I am youngest yet my stomach is great:
Nor it is not father, friends, nor any one,
Shall make me wed the man I cannot love:
I will have my will i'faith, i'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Let us determine Sisters what to do,
My father means to wed us in the morning,
And therefore something must be thought upon.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: We will to our father and so know his mind,
Aye and his reason too, we are no fools,
Or Babes neither, to be fed with words.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Agreed, agreed: but who shall speak for all?

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: No I.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Thou wilt not speak for crying.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Yes, yes I warrant you, that humor is left,
Be I but moved a little, I shall speak,
And anger him I fear, ere I have done.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whom Anthony our friend, our Schoolmaster?
Now help us Gentle Anthony, or never.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: What is your hasty running changed to prayer,
Say, where were you going?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Even to our father,
To know what he intends to do with us.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: It is bootless trust me, for he is resolved
To marry you to.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: The Strangers.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: I'faith he is.

sp.speaker: Math.
sp.l: I'faith he shall not.
Frenchman, be sure we will pluck a Crow together,
Before you force me give my hand at Church.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Come to our Father speech this comfort finds,
That we may scold out grief, and ease our minds.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Stay, Stay Marina, and advise you better,
It is not Force, but Policy must serve:
The Doors are locked, your Father keeps the Key,
Wherefore unpossible to scape away:
Yet have I plotted, and devised a drift,
To frustrate your intended marriages,
And give you full possession of your joys:
Laurentia, ere the mornings light appear,
You must play Anthony in my disguise.

sp.speaker: Math., Mari.
sp.l: Anthony, what of us? What shall we wear?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Soft, soft, you are too forward Girls, I swear,
For you some other drift devised must be?
One shadow for a substance: this is she.
Nay weep not sweets, repose upon my care,
For all alike, or good or bad shall share:
You will have Haruie, you Heigham, and you Ned;
You shall have all your wish, or be I dead:
For sooner may one day the Sea lie still,
Than once restrain a Woman of her will.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Sweet Anthony, how shall we quit thy hire?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Not gifts, but your contentments I desire:
To help my Countrymen I cast about,
For Strangers loves blaze fresh, but soon burn out:
Sweet rest dwell here, and frightful fear abjure,
These eyes shall wake to make your rest secure:
For ere again dull night the dull eyes charms,
Each one shall fold her Husband in her arms:
Which if it chance, we may avouch it still,
Women and Maids will always have their will.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Are Wood and Coals brought up to make a fire?
Is the Meat spitted ready to lie down:
For Bake-meats I will have none, the world is too hard:
There is Geese too, now I remember me;
Bid Mawdlin lay the Giblets in Past,
Here is nothing thought upon, but what I do.
Stay Frisco, see who rings: look to the Door,
Let none come in I charge, were he my Father,
I will keep them whilst I have them: Frisco, who is it?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: She is come i'faith.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Who is come?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Mistress Susnaunce, Mistress Moores daughter.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Mistress Susan, Ass? O she must come in.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: Hang him, if he keep out a Wench:
If the Wench keep not out him, so it is.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Welcome Mistress Susan, welcome;
I little thought you would have come tonight;
But welcome (trust me) are you to my house:
What, doth your Mother mend? doth she recover?
I promise you I am sorry for her sickness.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: She is better than she was, I thank God for it,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Now afore God she is a sweet smug Girl,
One might do good on her; the flesh is frail,
Man hath infirmity, and such a Bride,
Were able to change Age to hot desire:
Hark you Sweet-heart,
Tomorrow are my Daughters to be wed,
I pray you take the pains to go with them.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: If sir you will give me leave, I will wait on them.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Yes marry shall you, and a thousand thanks,
Such company as you my Daughters want,
Maids must grace Maids, when they are married:
Is it not a merry life (thinks thou) to wed,
For to embrace, and be embraced abed.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I know not what you mean sir.
Here is an old Ferret Pol-cat.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You may do, if you will follow mine advice;
I tell thee Mouse, I knew a Wench as nice:
Well, she is at rest poor soul, I mean my Wife,
That thought (alas good heart) Love was a toy,
Until (well, that time is gone and past away)
But why speak I of this: Hark ye Sweeting,
There is more in Wedlock, than the name can show;
And now (By our lady) you are ripe in years:
And yet take heed Wench, there lies a Pad in Straw;

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Old Fornicator, had I my Dagger,
I would break his Costard.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Young men are slippery, fickle, wavering;
Constant abiding graceth none but Age:
Then Maids should now wax wise, and do so,
As to choose constant men, let fickle go,
Youth is unregarded, and unhonoured:
An ancient Man doth make a Maid a Matron:
And is not that an Honour, how say you? how say you?

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Yes forsooth.
(O old lust will you never let me go.)

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You say right well, and do but think thereon,
How Husbands, honoured years, long card-for wealth,
Wise staidness, Experient government,
Doth grace the Maid, that thus is made a Wife,
And you will wish yourself such, on my life.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: I think I must turn womankind altogether,
And scratch out his eyes:
For as long as he can see me, he will never let me go.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: But go (sweet-heart) to bed, I do thee wrong,
The lateness now, makes all our talk seem long.
How now Mowche, be the Girls abed?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Mathea (if it like you) fain would sleep, but only tarrieth for her bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Ha, you say well: come, light her to her Chamber,
Good rest wish I to thee; wish so to me,
Then Susan and Pisaro shall agree:
Think but what joy is near your bed-fellow,
Such may be yours; take counsel of your Pillow:
Tomorrow we will talk more; and so good night,
Think what is said, may be, if all hit right.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: What, have I past the Pikes: knows he not Ned?
I think I have deserved his Daughters bed.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: It is well, it is well: but this let me request,
You keep unknown, till you be laid to rest:
And then a good hand speed you.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Tut, never fear me,
We two abed shall never disagree.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: I have stood still all this while, and could not speak for laughing: Lord what a Dialogue hath there been between Age and Youth. You do good on her? even as much as my Dutchman will do on my young Mistress: Master, follow my counsel; then send for M. Heigham to help him, for I will lay my Cap to two Pence, that he will be asleep tomorrow at night, when he should go to bed to her: Marry for the Italian, he is of another humour, for there will be no dealings with him, till midnight; for he must slaver all the Wenches in the house at parting, or he is nobody: he hath been but a little while at our House, yet in that small time, he hath licked more Grease from our Mawdlins lips, than would have served London Kitchen stuff this twelve-month. Yet for my money, well fare the Frenchman, O he is a forward Lad, for he will no sooner come from the Church, but he will fly to the Chamber; why he will read his Lesson so often in the day time, that at night like an apt Scholar, he will be ready to sell his old Book to buy him a new. O the generation of Languages that our House will bring forth: why every Bed will have a proper speech to himself, and have the Founders name written upon it in fair Capital letters, Here lay, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You will be a villain still: Look who is at door?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p:
Nay by the Mass, you are M. Porter, for I will be hanged if you lose that office, having so pretty a morsel under your keeping: I go (old huddle) for the best Nose at smelling out a Pin-fold, that I know: well, take heed, you may haps pick up Worms so long, that at length
some of them get into your Nose, and never out after: But what an Ass am I to think so, considering all the Lodgings are taken up already, and there is not a Dog-kennel empty for a strange Worm to breed in.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: The day is broke; Mathea and young Ned,
By this time, are so surely linked together,
That none in London can forbid the Banes.
Laurentia she is near provided for:
So that if Haruies policy but hold,
Else-where the Strangers may go seek them Wives:
But here they come.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Six o'clock say you; trust me, forward days:
Hark you Mowche, hie you to Church,
Bid M. Bewford be in readiness:
Where go you, that way?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: For my Cloak, sir.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: O it is well: and M. Brown,
Trust me, your early stirring makes me muse,
Is it to me your business?

sp.speaker: Brown.
sp.l: Even to yourself:
I come (I think) to bring you welcome news,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: And welcome news,
More welcome makes the bringer:
Speak, speak, good M. Brown, I long to hear them.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Then this it is. Young Haruie late last night,
Full weak and sickly came unto his lodging,
From whence this sudden malady proceeds:
It is all uncertain, the Doctors and his Friends
Affirm his health is unrecoverable:
Young Heigham and Ned Walgraue lately left him,
And I came hither to inform you of it.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Young M. Haruie sick; now afore God
The news bites near the Bone: for should he die,
His Living mortgaged would be redeemed,
For not these three months doth the Bond bear date:
Die now, marry God in heaven defend it;
O my sweet Lands, lose thee, nay lose my life:
And which is worst, I dare not ask mine own,
For I take two and twenty in the hundred,
When the Law gives but ten: But should he live,
He careless would have left the debt unpaid,
Then had the Lands been mine Pisaros own,
Mine, mine own Land, mine own Possession.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Nay hear me out.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: You are out too much already,
Unless you give him life, and me his Land.

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: Whether it is love to you, or to your Daughter,
I know not certain; but the Gentleman
Hath made a deed of gift of all his Lands,
Unto your beauteous Daughter fair Marina.

sp.speaker: Pesa.
sp.l: Ha, say that word again, say it again,
A good thing cannot be too often spoken:
Marina say you, are you sure it was she,
Or Mary, Margery; or some other Maid?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: To none but your Daughter fair Marina,
And for the gift might be more forcible,
Your neighbour master Moore advised us,
(Who is a witness of young Haruies Will)
Sick as he is, to bring him to your house:
I know they are not far, but do attend,
That they may know, what welcome they shall have.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What welcome sir; as welcome as new life
Given to the poor condemned Prisoner:
Return (good master Brown) assure their welcome,
Say it, nay swear it; for they are welcome truly:
For welcome are they to me which bring Gold.
See down who knocks; it may be there they are:
Frisco, call down my Sons, bid the Girls rise:
Where is Mowche; what, is he gone or no?
O hear you sirrah, bring along with you
Master Balsaro the Spanish Merchant.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Many Balsaros I; I will to my Love:
And thanks to Anthony for this escape.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Stay, take us with you. Hark, they knock again,
Come my souls comfort, thou good news bringer,
I must needs hug thee even for pure affection.

body.stage: Enter Haruie brought in a Chaire, Moore, Browne, Aluaro, Vandalle, Delion, and Frisco.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Lift softly (good my friends) for hurting him.
Look cheerly sir, you are welcome to my house.
Hark M. Vandalle, and my other Sons,
Seem to be sad as grieving for his sickness,
But inwardly rejoice. Master Uandalle,
Seignior Aluaro, Monsieur Delion,
Bid my Friend welcome, pray bid him welcome:
Take a good heart; I doubt not (by Gods leave)
You shall recover and do well enough:
(If I should think so, I should hang myself.)
Frisco, go bid Marina come to me.
You are a Witness sir, of this man's Will:
What think you M. Moore, what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, follow mine advice:
You see the Gentleman cannot escape,
Then let him straight be wedded to your Daughter;
So during life time, she shall hold his Land,
When now (being nor kith nor kin to him)
For all the deed of Gift, that he hath sealed,
His younger Brother will enjoy the Land.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Marry my Daughter: no By our lady.
Hear you Aluaro, my Friend counsel me,
Seeing young M. Haruie is so sick,
To marry him incontinent to my Daughter.
Or else the gift he hath bestowed, is vain:
Marry if he recover; no my Son,
I will not lose thy love, for all his Land.

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: Hear you padre, do no lose his Lands, his hundred pont per anno it is worth to have; let him have the mistress Marina in the marriage, it is but for me to attend one day more: if he will no die, I shall give him such a Drink, such a Potion shall make him give the Bonos noches to all the world.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Aluaro, here is my Keys, take all I have,
My Money, Plate, Wealth, Jewels, Daughter too:
Now God be thanked, that I have a Daughter,
worthy to be Aluaroes bedfellow:
O how I do admire and praise thy wit,
I will straight about it: Hear you Master Moore.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: Nay faith he is sick, therefore though he be come, yet he can do you no good; there is no remedy but even to put yourself into the hands of the Italian, that by that time that he hath past his growth, young Haruie will be in case to come upon it with a sise of fresh force.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Is my Love come, and sick? Aye now thou lovest me,
How my heart joys: O God, get I my will,
I will drive away that Sickness with a kiss:
I need not fain, for I could weep for joy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: It shall be so; come hither Daughter.
Master Haruie, that you may see my love
Comes from a single heart unfeignedly,
See here my Daughter, her I make thine own:
Nay look not strange, before these Gentlemen,
I freely yield Marina for thy Wife.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Stay, stay good sir, forbear this idle work,
My soul, is labouring for a higher place,
Than this vain transitory world can yield:
What, would you wed your Daughter to a Grave?
For this is but Deaths model in man's shape:
You and Aluaro happy live together:
Happy were I, to see you live together.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Come sir, I trust you shall do well again:
Here, here, it must be so; God give you joy,
And bless you (not a day to live together.)

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.p: Hort ye broder, will ye let den ander have your Wiue? nempt haer, nempt haer your selue ?

sp.speaker: Alua.
sp.p: No, no; tush you be the fool, here be that shall spoil the marriage of hem: you have deceive me of the fine Wench seignior Haruey, but I shall deceive you of the mush Land.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Are all things sure Father, is all despatched?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What interest we have, we yield it you:
Are you now satisfied, or rests there aught?

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: Nay Father, nothing doth remain, but thanks:
Thanks to yourself first, that disdaining me,
Yet loved my Lands, and for them gave a Wife.
But next, unto Aluaro let me turn,
To courteous gentle loving kind Aluaro,
That rather than to see me die for love,
For very love, would lose his beauteous Love.

sp.speaker: Vand.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Deli.
sp.p: Seignior Aluaro, give him the ting quickly shall make him die, autrement you shall lose the fine Wench.

p.foreign: Oyime che hauesse allhora appressata la mano al mio core, ô suen curato ate, I che longo sei tu arriuato, ô cieli, ô terra.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Am I awake? or do deluding Dreams
Make that seem true, which most my soul did fear?

sp.speaker: Haru
sp.l: Nay faith Father, it is very certain true,
I am as well as any man on earth:
Am I sick sirs? Look here, is Haruie sick?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What shall I do? What shall I say?
Did not you counsel me to wed my Child?
What Potion? Where is your help, your remedy.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: I hope more happy Stars will reign today,
And don Aluaro have more company.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Now Anthony, this cottons as it should,
And everythin sorts to his wished effect:
Haruie joys Moll: my Dutchman and the French,
Thinking all sure, laughs at Aluaros hap;
But quickly I shall mar that merry vain,
And make your Fortunes equal with your Friends.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Sirrah Mowche, what answer brought you back?
Will master Balsaro come, as I requested?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Master Balsaro; I know not who you mean.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Know you not Ass, did I not send thee for him?
Did not I bid thee bring him, with the Parson?
What answer made he, will he come or no?

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sent me for him: why sir, you sent not me,
I neither went for him, nor for the Parson:
I am glad to see your Worship is so merry.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Hence you forgetful dolt:
Look down who knocks?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: O Master, hang yourself: nay never stay for a Sessions: Master Vandalle confess yourself, desire the people to pray for you; for your Bride she is gone: Laurentia is run away.

sp.speaker: Vanda.
sp.l: O de Diabolo, the bad-fortune: is mistress Laurentia gone away?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: First tell me that I am a lifeless coarse;
Tell me of Doomsday, tell me what you will,
Before you say Laurentia is gone.

sp.speaker: Mari.
sp.l: Master Vandalle, how do you feel yourself?
What, hang the head? fie man for shame I say,
Look not so heavy on your marriage day.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: O blame him not, his grief is quickly spied,
That is a Bridegroom, and yet wants his Bride.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, and Gentlemen, good day to all:
According sir, as you requested me,
This morn I made repair unto the Tower,
Where as Laurentia now was married:
And sir, I did expect your coming thither;
Yet in your absence, we performed the rites:
Therefore I pray sir, bid God give them joy.

sp.speaker: Heigh.
sp.l: He tells you true, Laurentia is my Wife;
Who knowing that her Sisters must be wed;
Presuming also, that you will bid her welcome,
Are come to bear them company to Church.

sp.speaker: Haru.
sp.l: You come too late, the Marriage rites are done:
Yet welcome twenty-fold unto the Feast.
How say you sirs, did not I tell you true,
These Wenches would have us, and none of you.

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: I cannot say for these; but on my life,
This loves a Cushion better than a Wife.

sp.speaker: Mall.
sp.l: And reason too, that Cushion fell out right,
Else hard had been his lodging all last night.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, why stand you speechless thus?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Anger, and extreme grief enforceth me.
Pray sir, who bade you meet me at the Tower?

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.l: Who sir; your man sir, Mowche; here he is.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Who I sir, mean you me? you are a jesting man.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Thou art a Villain, a dissembling Wretch,
Worser than Anthony whom I kept last:
Fetch me an Officer, I will hamper you,
And make you sing at Bride-well for this trick:
For well he hath deserved it, that would swear
He went not forth a-doors at my appointment.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: So swear I still, I went not forth today.

sp.speaker: Bals.
sp.l: Why arrant liar, wert thou not with me?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: How say you master Brown, went he not forth?

sp.speaker: Brow.
sp.l: He, or his likeness did, I know not whether.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: What likeness can there be besides himself?

sp.speaker: Laur.
sp.l: Myself (forsooth) that took his shape upon me,
I was that Mowche that you sent from home:
And that same Mowche that deceived you,
Effected to possess this Gentleman:
Which to attain, I thus beguiled you all.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: This is excellent, this is as fine as a Fiddle: you M. Heigham got the Wench in Mowches apparel; now let Mowche put on her apparel, and be married to the Dutchman: How think you, is it not a good vise?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, shake off melancholy,
When things are helpless, patience must be used.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Talk of Patience? I will not bear these wrongs:
Go call down Matt, and mistress Susan Moore,
It is well that of all three, we have one sure.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Mistress Susan Moore, who do you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Whom should I mean sir, but your Daughter?

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: You are very pleasant sir: but tell me this,
When did you see her, that you speak of her?

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Aye late yesternight, when she came here to bed.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: You are deceived, my Daughter lay not here,
But watched with her sick mother all last night.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am glad you are so pleasant M. Moore,
You are loath that Susan should be held a sluggard:
What man, it was late before she went to bed,
And therefore time enough to rise again.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, do you flout your friends;
I well perceive if I had troubled you,
I should have had it in my dish ere now:
Susan lie here? am sure when I came forth,
I left her fast asleep in bed at home;
It is more than neighbour-hood to use me thus.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: A-bed at your house? tell me I am mad,
Did not I let her in adores myself,
Spoke to her, talked with her, and canvased with her;
And yet she lay not here? What say you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: She did, she did; I brought her to her Chamber.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: I say he lies (that saith so) in his throat.

sp.speaker: Antho.
sp.l: Mass now I remember me, I lie indeed.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: O how this frets me: Frisco, what say you?

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.p: What say I? Marry I say, if she lay not here, there was a familiar in her likeness; for I am sure my Master and she were so familiar together that he had almost shot the Gout out of his Toes ends, to make the Wench believe he had one trick of youth in him. Yet now I remember me she did not lie here; and the reason is, because she doth lie here, and is now abed with mistress Mathea; witness whereof, I have set to my Hand and Seal, and mean presently to fetch her.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Do so Frisco. Gentlemen and Friends,
Now shall you see how I am wronged by him.
Lay she not here? I think the world is grown wise,
Plain folks (as I) shall not know how to live.

sp.speaker: Frisc.
sp.l: She comes, she comes: a Hall, a Hall.

body.stage: Enter Mathea, and Walgraue in Womans attire.

sp.speaker: Walg.
sp.l: Nay blush not wench, fear not, look cheerfully.
Good morrow Father; Good morrow Gentlemen:
Nay stare not, look you here, no monster I,
But even plain Ned: and here stands Matt my Wife.
Know you her Frenchman? But she knows me better.
Father, pray Father, let me have your blessing,
For I have blessed you with a goodly Son;
It is breeding here i'faith, a jolly Boy.

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: I am undone, a reprobate, a slave;
A scorn, a laughter, and a jesting stock:
Give me my Child, give me my Daughter from you.

sp.speaker: Moor.
sp.l: Master Pisaro, it is in vain to fret,
And fume, and storm, it little now avails:
These Gentlemen have with your Daughters help,
Outstripped you in your subtle enterprises:
And therefore, seeing they are well descended,
Turn hate to love, and let them have their Loves,

sp.speaker: Pisa.
sp.l: Is it even so; why then I see that still,
Do what we can, Women will have their Will.
Gentlemen, you have outreached me now,
Which never before you, any yet could do:
You, that I thought should be my Sons indeed,
Must be content, since there is no hope to speed:
Others have got, what you did think to gain;
And yet believe me, they have took some pain.
Well, take them, there; and with them, God give joy.
And Gentlemen, I do entreat tomorrow,
That you will Feast with me, for all this sorrow:
Though you are wedded, yet the Feast is not made:
Come let us in, for all the storms are past,
And heaps of joy will follow on as fast.
